affection.title: Piyatara sutta - Dearer
affection.description: King Pasenadi of Kosala and Queen Mallikā discuss who is dearer to them.

affection.title: Bhadraka sutta - With Bhadraka
affection.description: The Buddha explains to the headman Bhadraka the root cause of suffering through a direct and relatable inquiry. When Bhadraka admits to feeling sorrow when those he cares about are harmed, the Buddha skillfully reveals that such sorrow arises not from the events themselves but from one’s own attachment and desire.

affection.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
affection.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

appreciative joy.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
appreciative joy.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

appreciative joy.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
appreciative joy.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

appreciative joy.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
appreciative joy.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

appreciative joy.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
appreciative joy.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

appreciative joy.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
appreciative joy.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

celibacy.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
celibacy.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

celibacy.title: Āpāyika sutta - Destined for Suffering
celibacy.description: The Buddha describes the two behaviors that lead to suffering and rebirth in hell if not abandoned.

collectedness.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
collectedness.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

collectedness.title: Chandasamādhi sutta - Collectedness Arising From Aspiration
collectedness.description: An analysis of the four bases of psychic powers that are endowed with collectedness arising from aspiration, determination, purification of mind, and investigation.

collectedness.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
collectedness.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

collectedness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
collectedness.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

collectedness.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
collectedness.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

collectedness.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
collectedness.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

collectedness.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
collectedness.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

collectedness.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
collectedness.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

collectedness.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
collectedness.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

collectedness.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
collectedness.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

collectedness.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
collectedness.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

collectedness.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
collectedness.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

collectedness.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
collectedness.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

collectedness.title: Upaparikkha sutta - Examining
collectedness.description: The Buddha instructs that one should examine experience in such a way that consciousness does not become scattered among external sense objects, fixated internally, or entangled through grasping.

collectedness.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
collectedness.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

collectedness.title: Sakkāra sutta - Respect
collectedness.description: The Blessed One describes how beings are affected by respect and disrespect, and how this affects their rebirth. The true person is one who is collected, detached, and delights in the ending of grasping.

collectedness.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

collectedness.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

collectedness.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

collectedness.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
collectedness.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

collectedness.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
collectedness.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

collectedness.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
collectedness.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

collectedness.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
collectedness.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

collectedness.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
collectedness.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

collectedness.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

collectedness.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

collectedness.title: Pañcaṅgika sutta - Fivefold
collectedness.description: The Buddha teaches the cultivation of the noble fivefold right collectedness with vivid similes, and shares how one who has cultivated this can realize any phenomenon realizable by directly knowing.

collectedness.title: Paṭhama uruvela sutta - Uruvelā (First)
collectedness.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

collectedness.title: Andha sutta - Blind
collectedness.description: The Buddha describes three types of people - the blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

collectedness.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
collectedness.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

complete comprehension.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
complete comprehension.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

complete comprehension.title: Orambhāgiya sutta - Lower Fetters
complete comprehension.description: The five lower fetters - 1) personality view, 2) doubt, 3) attachment to rites and rituals, 4) sensual desire, and 5) ill will - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five lower fetters.

complete comprehension.title: Upādānakkhandha sutta - Aggregates Subject to Clinging
complete comprehension.description: The five aggregates that are subject to clinging - 1) form, 2) feeling, 3) perception, 4) intentional constructions, and 5) consciousness - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five aggregates that are subject to clinging.

complete comprehension.title: Nīvaraṇa sutta - Hindrances
complete comprehension.description: The five hindrances - 1) sensual desire, 2) ill will, 3) dullness and drowsiness, 4) restlessness and worry, and 5) doubt - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

complete comprehension.title: Kāmaguṇa sutta - Cords of Sensual Pleasure
complete comprehension.description: The five cords of sensual pleasure are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five cords of sensual pleasure.

complete comprehension.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
complete comprehension.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

complete comprehension.title: Gantha sutta - Knots
complete comprehension.description: The four knots of 1) craving, 2) ill will, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to the idea that 'This is the truth' are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these knots.

complete comprehension.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
complete comprehension.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

complete comprehension.title: Sabbupādānapariññā sutta - Complete Comprehension of All Clinging
complete comprehension.description: The Buddha teaches the Dhamma for the complete comprehension of all clinging through seeing the dependent co-arising of feeling through the six sense bases.

complete comprehension.title: Paṭhama aparijānana sutta - Not Completely Comprehending (First)
complete comprehension.description: Everything, when not directly known, not completely comprehended, not detached from, and not let go of, is incapable of resulting in the wearing away of suffering.

complete comprehension.title: Pariñña sutta - Full Understanding
complete comprehension.description: The Buddha teaches the things to be fully understood and what full understanding is.

complete comprehension.title: Mahādukkhakkhandha sutta - The Greater Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
complete comprehension.description: The Buddha explains how to completely comprehend the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures, form, and felt experience.

complete comprehension.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
complete comprehension.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

complete comprehension.title: Diṭṭhigata sutta - Two Kinds Of Wrong Views
complete comprehension.description: Overcome by two kinds of wrong views, some get stuck, while others overreach. But those with vision see.

complete comprehension.title: Loka sutta - World
complete comprehension.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

complete comprehension.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
complete comprehension.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

complete comprehension.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
complete comprehension.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

compassion.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

compassion.title: Ekapuggala vagga - The Chapter On One Person
compassion.description: The Buddha describes the unique qualities of the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the perfectly Awakened One.

conscience.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
conscience.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

conscience.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

conscience.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
conscience.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

conscience.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
conscience.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

conscience.title: Dutiya dāna sutta - Giving (Second)
conscience.description: Wholesome giving along with faith and a sense of right and wrong is the way of practice that leads to the world of gods.

conscience.title: Paṭhamahatthaka sutta - With Hatthaka (First)
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the seven wonderful and marvelous qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he learns about this from a certain bhikkhu, Hatthaka is concerned if any other householder heard the praise. Learning of this, the Buddha adds contentment as the eighth wonderful and marvelous quality of Hatthaka.

conscience.title: Ugga sutta - Ugga
conscience.description: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike the seven kinds of wealth the Buddha describes which cannot be taken away.

conscience.title: Vitthatadhana sutta - Wealth in Detail
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in detail, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom. One who possesses these is not truly poor, and their life is not lived in vain.

conscience.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in brief, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom.

conscience.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

conscience.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
conscience.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

conscience.title: Dutiyaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (Second)
conscience.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) conscience, and 6) moral dread. The Buddha confirms these as conditions for stability and progress on the path.

contemplation.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
contemplation.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

contemplation.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
contemplation.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

contemplation.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
contemplation.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

contentment.title: Visākhā sutta - Visākha
contentment.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance to Visākhā on how all under another's control brings suffering.

contentment.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
contentment.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

contentment.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
contentment.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

contentment.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

contentment.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
contentment.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

contentment.title: Sulabha sutta - Easily Obtained
contentment.description: The Buddha describes contentment with the four easily obtained and blameless things as a factor of the spiritual life.

contentment.title: Bāla vagga - Chapter 5 - Immature
contentment.description: DhammaPada verses 60-75 describe the traits and consequences for an immature person. They suffer from delusion, cling to false views of self and possessions, perform harmful actions, seek status without wisdom, and long for recognition. In contrast, the wise avoid their company and pursue seclusion and true understanding of the Dhamma.

contentment.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
contentment.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

contentment.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
contentment.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

contentment.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
contentment.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

contentment.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
contentment.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

contentment.title: Paṭhamahatthaka sutta - With Hatthaka (First)
contentment.description: The Buddha describes the seven wonderful and marvelous qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he learns about this from a certain bhikkhu, Hatthaka is concerned if any other householder heard the praise. Learning of this, the Buddha adds contentment as the eighth wonderful and marvelous quality of Hatthaka.

contentment.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
contentment.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

contentment.title: Bhojana sutta - Food
contentment.description: The giver of food gives five things to the recipients - life, beauty, happiness, strength, and eloquence. They also find happiness as a result of their giving.

contentment.title: Vitthāra sutta - Kamma in Detail
contentment.description: The Buddha describes the four kinds of kamma (actions) and their results in detail.

contentment.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
contentment.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

contentment.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
contentment.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

contentment.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
contentment.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

contentment.title: Pasādakaradhamma vagga - Qualities Inspiring Confidence
contentment.description: The Buddha shares qualities that inspire confidence in the spiritual life.

contentment.title: Akammaniya vagga - The Chapter On The Ineffective
contentment.description: The Buddha contrasts the undeveloped and developed mind.

continuous effort.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
continuous effort.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

continuous effort.title: Tevijja sutta - Possessing the Threefold Knowledge
continuous effort.description: The Buddha describes a brahmin possessing the threefold knowledge through the Dhamma, not through mere repetition of what is said. This includes the recollection of past lives, the divine eye seeing beings’ rebirths according to kamma, and the realization of liberation through the wearing away of mental defilements.

continuous effort.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
continuous effort.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

continuous effort.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
continuous effort.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

continuous effort.title: Cara sutta - Walking
continuous effort.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

continuous effort.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
continuous effort.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

continuous effort.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
continuous effort.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

continuous effort.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
continuous effort.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

continuous effort.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
continuous effort.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

continuous effort.title: Cara sutta - Walking
continuous effort.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

continuous effort.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
continuous effort.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

cultivation.title: Jaṭā sutta - Knot
cultivation.description: The Buddha explains how the tangle of defilements can be disentangled through the practice of virtue, meditation, and wisdom.

cultivation.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
cultivation.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

cultivation.title: Orambhāgiya sutta - Lower Fetters
cultivation.description: The five lower fetters - 1) personality view, 2) doubt, 3) attachment to rites and rituals, 4) sensual desire, and 5) ill will - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five lower fetters.

cultivation.title: Upādānakkhandha sutta - Aggregates Subject to Clinging
cultivation.description: The five aggregates that are subject to clinging - 1) form, 2) feeling, 3) perception, 4) intentional constructions, and 5) consciousness - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five aggregates that are subject to clinging.

cultivation.title: Nīvaraṇa sutta - Hindrances
cultivation.description: The five hindrances - 1) sensual desire, 2) ill will, 3) dullness and drowsiness, 4) restlessness and worry, and 5) doubt - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

cultivation.title: Kāmaguṇa sutta - Cords of Sensual Pleasure
cultivation.description: The five cords of sensual pleasure are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five cords of sensual pleasure.

cultivation.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
cultivation.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

cultivation.title: Gantha sutta - Knots
cultivation.description: The four knots of 1) craving, 2) ill will, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to the idea that 'This is the truth' are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these knots.

cultivation.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
cultivation.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

cultivation.title: Dutiya kassapa sutta - Kassapa (Second)
cultivation.description: The young deity Kassapa shares a verse on the instruction for a bhikkhu.

cultivation.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
cultivation.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

cultivation.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
cultivation.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

cultivation.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
cultivation.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

cultivation.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
cultivation.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

cultivation.title: Paṭisallāna sutta - Seclusion
cultivation.description: The Buddha instructs to dwell in seclusion, enjoying solitude, being devoted to tranquility of mind, meditating with diligence, being endowed with discernment, practicing in an empty dwelling.

cultivation.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
cultivation.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

cultivation.title: Paṇḍita vagga - Chapter 6 - The Wise
cultivation.description: DhammaPada verses 76-89 share on associating with a wise person, characteristics of such a person, the importance of joy in the Dhamma, the benefits of renunciation, and the qualities of a well cultivated mind.

cultivation.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

cultivation.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

cultivation.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

cultivation.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

cultivation.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

cultivation.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
cultivation.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

cultivation.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
cultivation.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

cultivation.title: Dānavatthu sutta - Grounds for Giving
cultivation.description: The Buddha describes eight motivations for giving, including giving out of desire, aversion, and fear.

cultivation.title: Paṭhama dāna sutta - Giving (First)
cultivation.description: The Buddha explains eight kinds of giving, including giving out of fear, giving to maintain a good reputation, and giving to purify the mind.

cultivation.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
cultivation.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

cultivation.title: Paṁsudhovaka sutta - The Dirt Rinser
cultivation.description: The Buddha uses the gradual purification of gold as a metaphor for mental cultivation through meditation. Just as a goldsmith removes coarse, medium, and subtle impurities until the gold is workable and radiant, a meditator abandons defilements in stages. This gradual refinement leads to deep collectedness of mind, forming the foundation for supernormal abilities and, ultimately, liberation.

cultivation.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
cultivation.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

cultivation.title: Akammaniya vagga - The Chapter On The Ineffective
cultivation.description: The Buddha contrasts the undeveloped and developed mind.

diligence.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
diligence.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

diligence.title: Uṭṭhāna sutta - Rise Up
diligence.description: Verses urging one to rise from negligence, train steadfastly for the state of peace, and not waste the fleeting opportunity of the present moment. The teaching emphasizes the urgency of effort with the imagery of the afflicted pierced by a dart and the King of Death misleading one who remains negligent.

diligence.title: Arahattapañhā sutta - Questions on Enlightenment
diligence.description: The Noble Eightfold Path is the path and the way of practice for the realization of enlightenment.

diligence.title: Vīṇopama sutta - Simile of the Lute
diligence.description: The Buddha explains how to rein in the mind when desire, passion, aversion, illusion, or repulsion arises in regard to the six sense bases using the simile of a watchman and an ox and the simile of a lute.

diligence.title: Paṭhama dārukkhandhopama sutta - Simile of the Wooden Log (First)
diligence.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a log of wood carried by a river to explain the eight obstacles to reaching Nibbāna.

diligence.title: Dutiyadasabala sutta - Ten Powers (Second)
diligence.description: The Buddha, endowed with the ten powers and four assurances, reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising. He then urges the bhikkhus to practice with diligence for their highest welfare as well as for the welfare of others.

diligence.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
diligence.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

diligence.title: Tevijja sutta - Possessing the Threefold Knowledge
diligence.description: The Buddha describes a brahmin possessing the threefold knowledge through the Dhamma, not through mere repetition of what is said. This includes the recollection of past lives, the divine eye seeing beings’ rebirths according to kamma, and the realization of liberation through the wearing away of mental defilements.

diligence.title: Dāna sutta - Giving
diligence.description: The Buddha distinguishes between two types of giving, sharing, and assistance—those based on material things and those based on the Dhamma. In each case, giving, sharing, and assisting with the Dhamma are declared the highest.

diligence.title: Devasadda sutta - Divine Sound
diligence.description: The Buddha describes three occasions when divine sounds arise among the gods.

diligence.title: Sikkhānisaṁsa sutta - With Training as Benefit
diligence.description: The Buddha advises to live with training as the benefit, wisdom as the north star, liberation as the essence, ruled by mindfulness.

diligence.title: Sulabha sutta - Easily Obtained
diligence.description: The Buddha describes contentment with the four easily obtained and blameless things as a factor of the spiritual life.

diligence.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
diligence.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

diligence.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
diligence.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

diligence.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
diligence.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

diligence.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
diligence.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

diligence.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
diligence.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

diligence.title: Dutiyaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (Second)
diligence.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) conscience, and 6) moral dread. The Buddha confirms these as conditions for stability and progress on the path.

diligence.title: Paṭhamaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (First)
diligence.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) diligence, and 6) courteousness. The Buddha affirms these qualities as supportive of progress toward Nibbāna.

diligence.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
diligence.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

diligence.title: Devadūta sutta - Divine Messengers
diligence.description: The Buddha describes the three divine messengers that appear among human beings and what happens to those who do not heed their message.

diligence.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
diligence.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

diligence.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
diligence.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

diligence.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
diligence.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

direct knowledge.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
direct knowledge.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five lower fetters.

The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

direct knowledge.title: Kāmaguṇa sutta - Cords of Sensual Pleasure
direct knowledge.description: The five cords of sensual pleasure are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five cords of sensual pleasure.

direct knowledge.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
direct knowledge.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. direct knowledge.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

direct knowledge.title: Paṭhama aparijānana sutta - Not Completely Comprehending (First)
direct knowledge.description: Everything, when not directly known, not completely comprehended, not detached from, and not let go of, is incapable of resulting in the wearing away of suffering.

direct knowledge.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
direct knowledge.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

direct knowledge.title: Vīmaṁsaka sutta - Examining
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha provides a detailed and rigorous method for examining a Teacher. By discerning the teacher’s mental qualities, through prolonged observation, questioning, and learning directly, one gradually realizes a certain aspect of the teaching and builds unshakeable confidence in both the teacher and the teachings.

direct knowledge.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

direct knowledge.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

direct knowledge.title: Tevijja sutta - Possessing the Threefold Knowledge
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha describes a brahmin possessing the threefold knowledge through the Dhamma, not through mere repetition of what is said. This includes the recollection of past lives, the divine eye seeing beings’ rebirths according to kamma, and the realization of liberation through the wearing away of mental defilements.

direct knowledge.title: Loka sutta - World
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

direct knowledge.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

direct knowledge.title: Samaṇabrāhmaṇa sutta - Ascetics and Brahmins
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha describes the true ascetic and brahmin as one who understands the four noble truths.

direct knowledge.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
direct knowledge.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

direct knowledge.title: Atta vagga - Chapter 12 - Self
direct knowledge.description: Dhammapada verses 157-166 emphasize self-discipline, personal responsibility, and inner mastery. A wise person must first establish themselves properly before guiding others, as self-mastery is difficult but essential. Purity and impurity are personal matters, and one should prioritize their own spiritual welfare over external concerns, for no one can purify another.

direct knowledge.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
direct knowledge.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

discernment.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
discernment.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

discernment.title: Uraga sutta - Serpent
discernment.description: Verses depicting the path to liberation through the central metaphor of a serpent shedding its skin. Each stanza illustrates how a bhikkhu abandons defilements like anger, passion, craving, and conceit, thereby casting off attachment to this world and the next.

discernment.title: Dutiyadvaya sutta - The Duality (Second)
discernment.description: Consciousness arises in dependence on the duality of the six sense bases and their respective objects. Contact arises through the meeting of these three things. Contacted, one feels, intends, and perceives.

discernment.title: Paṭhamadvaya sutta - The Duality (First)
discernment.description: The Buddha teaches the duality of the six sense bases and their respective objects.

discernment.title: Upavāṇasandiṭṭhika sutta - Directly Visible with Upavāṇa
discernment.description: The Buddha explains how the Dhamma is directly visible, immediate, inviting one to come and see, applicable, and to be personally experienced by the wise through the six sense bases.

discernment.title: Chappāṇakopama sutta - The Simile of the Six Animals
discernment.description: The Buddha explains how there is non-restraint and restraint with a simile of six animals with different domains and feeding grounds. He uses strong post or pillar as a designation for mindfulness directed to the body.

discernment.title: Udāyī sutta - With Udāyī
discernment.description: The venerable Udāyī asks the venerable Ānanda about how to see the not-self nature of consciousness.

discernment.title: Koṭṭhika sutta - Koṭṭhika
discernment.description: Venerable Mahākoṭṭhika asks Venerable Sāriputta if the eye is the fetter of forms or if forms are the fetter of the eye. Venerable Sāriputta explains that it is the desire and lust that arises in dependence on both that is the fetter.

discernment.title: Bāḷisikopama sutta - The Fisherman's Simile
discernment.description: The Buddha likens the six types of desirable sense objects to baited hooks, set in the world for the misfortune of beings—those who cling to them fall under Māra’s power.

discernment.title: Paṭhama samudda sutta - Ocean (First)
discernment.description: The Buddha uses the simile of an ocean to describe the six sense bases and their respective objects.

discernment.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
discernment.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

discernment.title: Sakkapañha sutta - Sakka's Question
discernment.description: The Buddha answers Sakka's question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very life.

discernment.title: Nagara sutta - The City
discernment.description: The Buddha recounts how he attained full awakening by examining the principle of dependent co-arising. He likens this realization to a man discovering an ancient, forgotten city.

discernment.title: Dutiyadasabala sutta - Ten Powers (Second)
discernment.description: The Buddha, endowed with the ten powers and four assurances, reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising. He then urges the bhikkhus to practice with diligence for their highest welfare as well as for the welfare of others.

discernment.title: Dasabala sutta - Ten Powers
discernment.description: Endowed with ten powers and four assurances, the Buddha reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising.

discernment.title: Samiddhi sutta - With Samiddhi
discernment.description: A radiant deity tempts young Samiddhi to enjoy sensual pleasures. The Buddha later reveals that true liberation transcends identity and craving, and is only found by those who let go of even the need to describe themselves.

discernment.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
discernment.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

discernment.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
discernment.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

discernment.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
discernment.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

discernment.title: Anaṅgaṇa sutta - Blemish Free
discernment.description: Venerable Sāriputta explains the four kinds of persons based on their understanding of blemishes and blemish-free qualities. He uses the simile of a bronze bowl to illustrate the importance of understanding one's blemishes and blemish-free qualities.

discernment.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
discernment.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

discernment.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
discernment.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

discernment.title: Mahādukkhakkhandha sutta - The Greater Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
discernment.description: The Buddha explains how to completely comprehend the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures, form, and felt experience.

discernment.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
discernment.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

discernment.title: Dāna sutta - Giving
discernment.description: The Buddha distinguishes between two types of giving, sharing, and assistance—those based on material things and those based on the Dhamma. In each case, giving, sharing, and assisting with the Dhamma are declared the highest.

discernment.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
discernment.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

discernment.title: Paṭisallāna sutta - Seclusion
discernment.description: The Buddha instructs to dwell in seclusion, enjoying solitude, being devoted to tranquility of mind, meditating with diligence, being endowed with discernment, practicing in an empty dwelling.

discernment.title: Ajāta sutta - Unborn
discernment.description: The Buddha shares on the state that is unborn, unbecome, unmade, and unconditioned, which is beyond the realm of thought and enduring.

discernment.title: Taṇhuppāda sutta - Uprisings of Craving
discernment.description: The Buddha describes the four uprisings of craving that can arise for a bhikkhu.

discernment.title: Āsavakkhaya sutta - Wearing Away of the Taints
discernment.description: When one knows and sees the four noble truths, there is the wearing away of the taints.

discernment.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
discernment.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

discernment.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

discernment.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

discernment.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

discernment.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

discernment.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

discernment.title: Sahassavagga - Chapter 8 - One Thousand
discernment.description: Dhammapada verses 100-115 share the importance of one teaching that brings peace, the benefits of self-conquest, the value of honoring the awakened, and the importance of rousing of energy and recognizing impermanence.

discernment.title: Sappurisadāna sutta - Gifts of a True Person
discernment.description: The Buddha explains the eight gifts of a true person, including giving what is pure, excellent, and at the proper time.

discernment.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
discernment.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

disenchantment.title: Sabbupādānapariññā sutta - Complete Comprehension of All Clinging
disenchantment.description: The Buddha teaches the Dhamma for the complete comprehension of all clinging through seeing the dependent co-arising of feeling through the six sense bases.

disenchantment.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
disenchantment.description: After examining the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, as not being suitable to identify with.

disenchantment.title: Gaṅgā sutta - Ganges
disenchantment.description: The Buddha explains to a brahmin that the cycle of existence is without a discoverable beginning, and that it is not easy to calculate the number of aeons that have passed by and gone.

disenchantment.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
disenchantment.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

disenchantment.title: Diṭṭhigata sutta - Two Kinds Of Wrong Views
disenchantment.description: Overcome by two kinds of wrong views, some get stuck, while others overreach. But those with vision see.

disenchantment.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
disenchantment.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

disenchantment.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
disenchantment.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

dispassion.title: Papañcakhaya sutta - Wearing Away of Mental Proliferation
dispassion.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance after reflecting on his own giving up of the proliferation of conceptual perceptions.

dispassion.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
dispassion.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

dispassion.title: Uraga sutta - Serpent
dispassion.description: Verses depicting the path to liberation through the central metaphor of a serpent shedding its skin. Each stanza illustrates how a bhikkhu abandons defilements like anger, passion, craving, and conceit, thereby casting off attachment to this world and the next.

dispassion.title: Upavāṇasandiṭṭhika sutta - Directly Visible with Upavāṇa
dispassion.description: The Buddha explains how the Dhamma is directly visible, immediate, inviting one to come and see, applicable, and to be personally experienced by the wise through the six sense bases.

dispassion.title: Sabbupādānapariññā sutta - Complete Comprehension of All Clinging
dispassion.description: The Buddha teaches the Dhamma for the complete comprehension of all clinging through seeing the dependent co-arising of feeling through the six sense bases.

dispassion.title: Paṭhama aparijānana sutta - Not Completely Comprehending (First)
dispassion.description: Everything, when not directly known, not completely comprehended, not detached from, and not let go of, is incapable of resulting in the wearing away of suffering.

dispassion.title: Paṭhama dārukkhandhopama sutta - Simile of the Wooden Log (First)
dispassion.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a log of wood carried by a river to explain the eight obstacles to reaching Nibbāna.

dispassion.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
dispassion.description: After examining the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, as not being suitable to identify with.

dispassion.title: Upaya sutta - Attachment
dispassion.description: Consciousness, while persisting, might persist attached to form, feeling, perception, and intentional constructions. When passion for these is abandoned, the support for the establishment of consciousness is completely cut off. That consciousness, being unestablished, does not grow, and by not intentionally constructing, is liberated.

dispassion.title: Pariñña sutta - Full Understanding
dispassion.description: The Buddha teaches the things to be fully understood and what full understanding is.

dispassion.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
dispassion.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

dispassion.title: Dutiya kassapa sutta - Kassapa (Second)
dispassion.description: The young deity Kassapa shares a verse on the instruction for a bhikkhu.

dispassion.title: Gaṅgā sutta - Ganges
dispassion.description: The Buddha explains to a brahmin that the cycle of existence is without a discoverable beginning, and that it is not easy to calculate the number of aeons that have passed by and gone.

dispassion.title: Māgaṇḍiya sutta - To Māgaṇḍiya
dispassion.description: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya holds the view that sensual indulgence is spiritual growth and harshly criticizes the Buddha for teaching sense restraint, calling him a destroyer of spiritual growth. The Buddha skilfully reveals the true nature of sensual pleasures through vivid similes such as a leper finding relief by scorching himself over burning coals and a blind man mistaking a filthy rag for a spotless white cloth.

dispassion.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
dispassion.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

dispassion.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
dispassion.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

dispassion.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
dispassion.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

dispassion.title: Sakkāra sutta - Respect
dispassion.description: The Blessed One describes how beings are affected by respect and disrespect, and how this affects their rebirth. The true person is one who is collected, detached, and delights in the ending of grasping.

dispassion.title: Diṭṭhigata sutta - Two Kinds Of Wrong Views
dispassion.description: Overcome by two kinds of wrong views, some get stuck, while others overreach. But those with vision see.

dispassion.title: Loka sutta - World
dispassion.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

dispassion.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
dispassion.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance.
