Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

dispassion.title: Taṇhā vagga - Chapter 24 - Craving
dispassion.description: Dhammapada verses 334–359 depict craving as a binding force, likening it to a creeping vine, a trapped hare, and a spider’s web. The wise cut these bonds, free from passion, aversion, illusion, and longing, crossing beyond birth and aging. The highest gift is the Dhamma, surpassing all wealth and pleasures, and the destruction of craving is the greatest victory. Offerings to those free from defilements bear the greatest fruit.

dispassion.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
dispassion.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

dispassion.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
dispassion.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

ending.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
ending.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

ending.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
ending.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

ending.title: Santatara sutta - More Peaceful than
ending.description: The formless existence is more peaceful than the form realm. Yet, cessation is more peaceful than the formless existence.

ending.title: Diṭṭhigata sutta - Two Kinds Of Wrong Views
ending.description: Overcome by two kinds of wrong views, some get stuck, while others overreach. But those with vision see.

ending.title: Cara sutta - Walking
ending.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

ending.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
ending.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

ending.title: Cara sutta - Walking
ending.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

ending.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
ending.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. equanimity.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
equanimity.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

equanimity.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
equanimity.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

equanimity.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
equanimity.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

equanimity.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
equanimity.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

equanimity.title: Dhammānudhammapaṭipanna sutta - Practicing in Accordance with the Dhamma
equanimity.description: It is natural for a practitioner practicing in accordance with the Dhamma to speak and think only in terms of the Dhamma, not in terms of what is not the Dhamma.

equanimity.title: Indriya sutta - Mental Faculties
equanimity.description: The Buddha describes the three mental faculties - the faculty that senses ‘I will know the unknown,’ the faculty of awakening, and the faculty of one who is awakened.

ethical conduct.title: Uposatha sutta - Uposatha
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha sits silently among the Saṅgha of bhikkhus on an Uposatha night when the assembly wasn't pure. Afterwards, the Buddha explains the eight wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Dhamma and Vinaya, likening them to similarly wonderful qualities of the great ocean.

ethical conduct.title: Jaṭā sutta - Knot
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha explains how the tangle of defilements can be disentangled through the practice of virtue, meditation, and wisdom.

ethical conduct.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

ethical conduct.title: Attarakkhita sutta - Self-Protection
ethical conduct.description: Even if protected by an entire army, one who engages in misconduct is unprotected. But one who engages in good conduct protects themselves, even without external protection.

ethical conduct.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
ethical conduct.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

ethical conduct.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

ethical conduct.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

ethical conduct.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
ethical conduct.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

ethical conduct.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

ethical conduct.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
ethical conduct.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

ethical conduct.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

ethical conduct.title: Sukhapatthanā sutta - Aspiring for Happiness
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha teaches that a wise person aspiring for the three kinds of happiness - of 1) praise, 2) wealth, and 3) good rebirth - should safeguard their virtue.

ethical conduct.title: Putta sutta - Child
ethical conduct.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

ethical conduct.title: Moneyya sutta - Sagacity
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of sagacity - by body, speech and mind.

ethical conduct.title: Soceyya sutta - Purity
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of purity - by body, speech and mind.

ethical conduct.title: Sucarita sutta - Good Conduct
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of good conduct - by body, speech and mind.

ethical conduct.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

ethical conduct.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

ethical conduct.title: Paṇḍita vagga - Chapter 6 - The Wise
ethical conduct.description: DhammaPada verses 76-89 share on associating with a wise person, characteristics of such a person, the importance of joy in the Dhamma, the benefits of renunciation, and the qualities of a well cultivated mind.

ethical conduct.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
ethical conduct.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

ethical conduct.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

ethical conduct.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

ethical conduct.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

ethical conduct.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

ethical conduct.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

ethical conduct.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
ethical conduct.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

ethical conduct.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
ethical conduct.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

ethical conduct.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
ethical conduct.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

ethical conduct.title: Paṭhamahatthaka sutta - With Hatthaka (First)
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the seven wonderful and marvelous qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he learns about this from a certain bhikkhu, Hatthaka is concerned if any other householder heard the praise. Learning of this, the Buddha adds contentment as the eighth wonderful and marvelous quality of Hatthaka.

ethical conduct.title: Ugga sutta - Ugga
ethical conduct.description: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike the seven kinds of wealth the Buddha describes which cannot be taken away.

ethical conduct.title: Vitthatadhana sutta - Wealth in Detail
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in detail, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom. One who possesses these is not truly poor, and their life is not lived in vain.

ethical conduct.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in brief, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom.

ethical conduct.title: Paṭhama uruvela sutta - Uruvelā (First)
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

ethical conduct.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
ethical conduct.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

ethical conduct.title: Aṭṭhāna vagga - The Chapter On The Impossible
ethical conduct.description: Short teachings on the impossibility of certain events, actions, or outcomes.

examination.title: Chandasamādhi sutta - Collectedness Arising From Aspiration
examination.description: An analysis of the four bases of psychic powers that are endowed with collectedness arising from aspiration, determination, purification of mind, and investigation.

examination.title: Nagara sutta - The City
examination.description: The Buddha recounts how he attained full awakening by examining the principle of dependent co-arising. He likens this realization to a man discovering an ancient, forgotten city.

examination.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
examination.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

examination.title: Vīmaṁsaka sutta - Examining
examination.description: The Buddha provides a detailed and rigorous method for examining a Teacher. By discerning the teacher’s mental qualities, through prolonged observation, questioning, and learning directly, one gradually realizes a certain aspect of the teaching and builds unshakeable confidence in both the teacher and the teachings.

examination.title: Mahādukkhakkhandha sutta - The Greater Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
examination.description: The Buddha explains how to completely comprehend the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures, form, and felt experience.

examination.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
examination.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

examination.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
examination.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

examination.title: Upaparikkha sutta - Examining
examination.description: The Buddha instructs that one should examine experience in such a way that consciousness does not become scattered among external sense objects, fixated internally, or entangled through grasping.

examination.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
examination.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

examination.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger

The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

faith.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
faith.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

faith.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
faith.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

faith.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
faith.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

faith.title: Vīmaṁsaka sutta - Examining
faith.description: The Buddha provides a detailed and rigorous method for examining a Teacher. faith.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
faith.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

faith.title: Dāna sutta - Giving
faith.description: The Buddha distinguishes between two types of giving, sharing, and assistance—those based on material things and those based on the Dhamma. In each case, giving, sharing, and assisting with the Dhamma are declared the highest.

faith.title: Pañcapubbanimitta sutta - Five Preceding Signs
faith.description: The Buddha describes the five signs that appear when a deity is about to pass away, and the three blessings that the gods give to the deity.

faith.title: Dutiya dāna sutta - Giving (Second)
faith.description: Wholesome giving along with faith and a sense of right and wrong is the way of practice that leads to the world of gods.

faith.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief

faith.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
faith.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

faith.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
faith.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

faith.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
faith.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

faith.title: Vesārajja sutta - Assurances
faith.description: The Buddha describes the four assurances possessed by the Tathāgata.

faith.title: Pasādakaradhamma vagga - Qualities Inspiring Confidence
faith.description: The Buddha shares qualities that inspire confidence in the spiritual life.

fear of wrongdoing.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

fear of wrongdoing.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
fear of wrongdoing.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

fear of wrongdoing.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

fear of wrongdoing.title: Dutiyaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (Second)
fear of wrongdoing.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) conscience, and 6) moral dread. The Buddha confirms these as conditions for stability and progress on the path.

flexible.title: Paṁsudhovaka sutta - The Dirt Rinser
flexible.description: The Buddha uses the gradual purification of gold as a metaphor for mental cultivation through meditation. Just as a goldsmith removes coarse, medium, and subtle impurities until the gold is workable and radiant, a meditator abandons defilements in stages. This gradual refinement leads to deep collectedness of mind, forming the foundation for supernormal abilities and, ultimately, liberation.

flexible.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
flexible.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

formless.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
formless.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

formless.title: Santatara sutta - More Peaceful than
formless.description: The formless existence is more peaceful than the form realm. Yet, cessation is more peaceful than the formless existence.

formless.title: Nissaraṇiya sutta - Escape
formless.description: The Buddha describes the three elements of escape - renunciation, formless existence and cessation.

full awareness.title: Samiddhi sutta - With Samiddhi
full awareness.description: A radiant deity tempts young Samiddhi to enjoy sensual pleasures. The Buddha later reveals that true liberation transcends identity and craving, and is only found by those who let go of even the need to describe themselves.

full awareness.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail

full awareness.title: Acchariyaabbhuta sutta - Wonderful and Marvelous
full awareness.description: Venerable Ānanda recollects the wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Tathāgata, the Buddha, relating to his conception and birth. The Buddha then caps it off by sharing what he considers the most wonderful and marvelous quality of all.

full awareness.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
full awareness.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

full awareness.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
full awareness.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

full awareness.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
full awareness.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

full awareness.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
full awareness.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

giving.title: Uttara sutta - Uttara
giving.description: A young deity recites a verse to the Buddha about the shortness of life and the importance of doing meritorious deeds.

giving.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
giving.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

giving.title: Avuṭṭhika sutta - Rainless
giving.description: Three kinds of persons are found in the world - 1) one like a rainless cloud, 2) one like a cloud that rains in a certain area, and 3) one like a cloud that rains everywhere.

giving.title: Bahukāra sutta - Very Helpful
giving.description: The Buddha describes how the spiritual life is lived in mutual dependence between monastics and householders for the sake of crossing over the flood and for the complete ending of suffering.

giving.title: Sabrahmaka sutta - With Brahmā
giving.description: Where children honor their mother and father, those families are said to dwell with Brahmā.

giving.title: Sappurisadāna sutta - Gifts of a True Person
giving.description: The Buddha explains the eight gifts of a true person, including giving what is pure, excellent, and at the proper time.

giving.title: Dānavatthu sutta - Grounds for Giving
giving.description: The Buddha describes eight motivations for giving, including giving out of desire, aversion, and fear.

giving.title: Dutiya dāna sutta - Giving (Second)
giving.description: Wholesome giving along with faith and a sense of right and wrong is the way of practice that leads to the world of gods.

giving.title: Paṭhama dāna sutta - Giving (First)
giving.description: The Buddha explains eight kinds of giving, including giving out of fear, giving to maintain a good reputation, and giving to purify the mind.

giving.title: Bhojana sutta - Food
giving.description: The giver of food gives five things to the recipients - life, beauty, happiness, strength, and eloquence. They also find happiness as a result of their giving.

giving.title: Kāladāna sutta - Suitable Time for Giving a Gift
giving.description: The Buddha describes five suitable times for giving a gift - to a guest, traveler, sick person, during famine, and to the virtuous.

giving.title: Sabrahmaka sutta - With Brahmā
giving.description: Where children honor their mother and father, those families are said to dwell with Brahmā.

giving.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
giving.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

giving up.title: Papañcakhaya sutta - Wearing Away of Mental Proliferation
giving up.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance after reflecting on his own giving up of the proliferation of conceptual perceptions.

giving up.title: Jatukaṇṇimāṇavapucchā - Jatukaṇṇi’s Questions
giving up.description: The venerable Jatukaṇṇi asks the Buddha on how to attain the state of peace and abandon birth and old age. The Buddha advises him to remove greed for sensual pleasures by seeing renunciation as safety, and to cease all grasping related to name and form in the past, future, as well as present.

giving up.title: Uraga sutta - Serpent
giving up.description: Verses depicting the path to liberation through the central metaphor of a serpent shedding its skin. Each stanza illustrates how a bhikkhu abandons defilements like anger, passion, craving, and conceit, thereby casting off attachment to this world and the next.

giving up.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
giving up.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

giving up.title: Paṭhama aparijānana sutta - Not Completely Comprehending (First)
giving up.description: Everything, when not directly known, not completely comprehended, not detached from, and not let go of, is incapable of resulting in the wearing away of suffering.

giving up.title: Paṭhama dārukkhandhopama sutta - Simile of the Wooden Log (First)
giving up.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a log of wood carried by a river to explain the eight obstacles to reaching Nibbāna.

giving up.title: Pahāna sutta - Giving Up
giving up.description: The Buddha teaches the Dhamma for the giving up of everything based on the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception.

giving up.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
giving up.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

giving up.title: Uttara sutta - Uttara
giving up.description: A young deity recites a verse to the Buddha about the shortness of life and the importance of doing meritorious deeds.

giving up.title: Sanidāna sutta - From A Cause
giving up.description: The Buddha explains how thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming arise from a cause and how to abandon them.

giving up.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
giving up.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

giving up.title: Māgaṇḍiya sutta - To Māgaṇḍiya
giving up.description: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya holds the view that sensual indulgence is spiritual growth and harshly criticizes the Buddha for teaching sense restraint, calling him a destroyer of spiritual growth. The Buddha skilfully reveals the true nature of sensual pleasures through vivid similes such as a leper finding relief by scorching himself over burning coals and a blind man mistaking a filthy rag for a spotless white cloth.

giving up.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
giving up.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

giving up.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
giving up.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

giving up.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding
giving up.description: The three unwholesome thoughts are blinding, produce lack of clarity, cause ignorance, obstruct wisdom, and are troublesome and not conducive to Nibbāna. The three wholesome thoughts give sight, produce clarity and create insight, grow wisdom, and are trouble-free and conducive to Nibbāna.

giving up.title: Nissaraṇiya sutta - Escape
giving up.description: The Buddha describes the three elements of escape - renunciation, formless existence and cessation.

giving up.title: Moneyya sutta - Sagacity
giving up.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of sagacity - by body, speech and mind.

giving up.title: Soceyya sutta - Purity
giving up.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of purity - by body, speech and mind.

giving up.title: Sucarita sutta - Good Conduct
giving up.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of good conduct - by body, speech and mind.

giving up.title: Cara sutta - Walking
giving up.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

giving up.title: Nadīsota sutta - River Current
giving up.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a person carried downstream by a lovely and alluring river current to illustrate the painful results of craving and indulgence in the internal sense bases.

giving up.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
giving up.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

giving up.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
giving up.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

giving up.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
giving up.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

giving up.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha
giving up.description: DhammaPada verses 179-196 describe the boundless and traceless nature of the Buddha, the teachings of all the Buddhas, rarity of a human birth, rarity of the arising of a Buddha, what is a safe refuge that leads to release from suffering, and the merit gained by ones who honor the Buddhas or their disciples.

giving up.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
giving up.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

giving up.title: Cara sutta - Walking
giving up.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

giving up.title: Paṁsudhovaka sutta - The Dirt Rinser
giving up.description: The Buddha uses the gradual purification of gold as a metaphor for mental cultivation through meditation. Just as a goldsmith removes coarse, medium, and subtle impurities until the gold is workable and radiant, a meditator abandons defilements in stages. This gradual refinement leads to deep collectedness of mind, forming the foundation for supernormal abilities and, ultimately, liberation.

good friendship.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
good friendship.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

good friendship.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
good friendship.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

good friendship.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
good friendship.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

good friendship.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
good friendship.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

good habits.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
good habits.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

good habits.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
good habits.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

humility.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
humility.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

humility.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
humility.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

humility.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
humility.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

humility.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
humility.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

humility.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
humility.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

impartiality.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
impartiality.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

impartiality.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
impartiality.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

inquisitiveness.title: Arahattapañhā sutta - Questions on Enlightenment
inquisitiveness.description: The Noble Eightfold Path is the path and the way of practice for the realization of enlightenment.

inquisitiveness.title: Dukkarapañhā sutta - Questions on What is Difficult to Do
inquisitiveness.description: Ven. Sāriputta answers the question of what is difficult to do in the teaching and discipline, and what is difficult for one who has gone forth.

joyful pleasure.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
joyful pleasure.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

joyful pleasure.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
joyful pleasure.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

knowledge.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
knowledge.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

knowledge.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
knowledge.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

knowledge.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
knowledge.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

learning.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
learning.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

learning.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
learning.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

learning.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
learning.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

learning.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
learning.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

learning.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
learning.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

learning.title: Paṭhamahatthaka sutta - With Hatthaka (First)
learning.description: The Buddha describes the seven wonderful and marvelous qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he learns about this from a certain bhikkhu, Hatthaka is concerned if any other householder heard the praise. Learning of this, the Buddha adds contentment as the eighth wonderful and marvelous quality of Hatthaka.

learning.title: Ugga sutta - Ugga
learning.description: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike the seven kinds of wealth the Buddha describes which cannot be taken away.

learning.title: Vitthatadhana sutta - Wealth in Detail
learning.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in detail, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom. One who possesses these is not truly poor, and their life is not lived in vain.

learning.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief
learning.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in brief, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom.

learning.title: Vibhatti sutta - Analytical Knowledges
learning.description: Venerable Sāriputta describes the four analytical knowledges he realized a half-month after his full ordination.

learning.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
learning.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

liberation.title: Uposatha sutta - Uposatha
liberation.description: The Buddha sits silently among the Saṅgha of bhikkhus on an Uposatha night when the assembly wasn't pure. Afterwards, the Buddha explains the eight wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Dhamma and Vinaya, likening them to similarly wonderful qualities of the great ocean.

liberation.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
liberation.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

liberation.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
liberation.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

liberation.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
liberation.description: After examining the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, as not being suitable to identify with.

liberation.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
liberation.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

liberation.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

liberation.title: Devasadda sutta - Divine Sound
liberation.description: The Buddha describes three occasions when divine sounds arise among the gods.

liberation.title: Loka sutta - World
liberation.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

liberation.title: Bahukāra sutta - Very Helpful
liberation.description: The Buddha describes how the spiritual life is lived in mutual dependence between monastics and householders for the sake of crossing over the flood and for the complete ending of suffering.

liberation.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
liberation.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

liberation.title: Arahanta vagga - Chapter 7 - The Awakened Being
liberation.description: Dhammapada verses 90-99 describe the qualities and conduct of the Arahant, a fully awakened being who has reached the end of the path. Free from defilements and clinging, their actions leave no trace, like birds in the sky. At peace and delighting in solitude, wherever they dwell becomes a place of beauty.

liberation.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
liberation.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

liberation.title: Paṭhama uruvela sutta - Uruvelā (First)
liberation.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

liberation.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
liberation.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

liberation.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
liberation.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

loving-kindness.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

loving-kindness.title: Sanidāna sutta - From A Cause
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains how thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming arise from a cause and how to abandon them.

loving-kindness.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
loving-kindness.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

loving-kindness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

loving-kindness.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

loving-kindness.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula

loving-kindness.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

loving-kindness.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

loving-kindness.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

loving-kindness.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

loving-kindness.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding

loving-kindness.title: Moneyya sutta - Sagacity

loving-kindness.title: Soceyya sutta - Purity
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of purity - by body, speech and mind.

loving-kindness.title: Sucarita sutta - Good Conduct
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of good conduct - by body, speech and mind.

loving-kindness.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

loving-kindness.title: Sukha vagga - Chapter 15 - Happiness
loving-kindness.description: DhammaPada verses 197-208 describe the happiness of those who live without hatred, affliction, and anxiety. It includes poetic verses on happiness and Nibbāna, and emphasizes seeing, dwelling, and association with the wise, noble ones.

loving-kindness.title: Mettā sutta - Loving-Kindness
loving-kindness.description: Eight benefits of cultivating loving-kindness from sleeping with ease to fire, poison, and weapons not harming one to going to the Brahma world.

loving-kindness.title: Vācā sutta - Speech
loving-kindness.description: Five factors of well-spoken speech are - 1) It is spoken at the proper time, 2) truthfully, 3) gently, 4) in a way that benefits, and 5) spoken with a mind of loving-kindness.

loving-kindness.title: Mettā sutta - Loving-Kindness
loving-kindness.description: 11 benefits of cultivating loving-kindness from sleeping with ease to dying unconfused to going to the Brahma world.

loving-kindness.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

loving-kindness.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
loving-kindness.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

merit.title: Ayyikā sutta - Grandmother
merit.description: King Pasenadi expresses deep sorrow over his grandmother's death. The Buddha teaches him that all beings, without exception, are subject to death and cannot escape it, likening it to a potter's pots that are all bound to break.

merit.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
merit.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

merit.title: Pañcapubbanimitta sutta - Five Preceding Signs
merit.description: The Buddha describes the five signs that appear when a deity is about to pass away, and the three blessings that the gods give to the deity.

merit.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
merit.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

merit.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
merit.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

merit.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
merit.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

merit.title: Kāladāna sutta - Suitable Time for Giving a Gift
merit.description: The Buddha describes five suitable times for giving a gift - to a guest, traveler, sick person, during famine, and to the virtuous.

merit.title: Vaṇijja sutta - Trade
merit.description: The Buddha describes the cause and condition for why a trade, once undertaken, leads to loss, fails to meet its intended aim, succeeds as intended, or surpasses even its intended aim.

merit.title: Adhamma vagga - The Chapter On Not The Teaching
merit.description: The Buddha shares the importance of explaining correctly what is not the Dhamma, Vinaya, spoken or uttered, practiced, and prescribed by the Tathāgata.

mindfulness.title: Mogharājamāṇavapucchā - Mogharāja’s Question
mindfulness.description: The venerable Mogharāja asks the Buddha how to look upon the world so that the King of Death does not see one. The Buddha advises to look upon the world as empty, being ever mindful, and to uproot the sense of self.

mindfulness.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
mindfulness.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

mindfulness.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

mindfulness.title: Chappāṇakopama sutta - The Simile of the Six Animals
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains how there is non-restraint and restraint with a simile of six animals with different domains and feeding grounds. He uses strong post or pillar as a designation for mindfulness directed to the body.

mindfulness.title: Samiddhi sutta - With Samiddhi
mindfulness.description: A radiant deity tempts young Samiddhi to enjoy sensual pleasures. The Buddha later reveals that true liberation transcends identity and craving, and is only found by those who let go of even the need to describe themselves.

mindfulness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
mindfulness.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

mindfulness.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

mindfulness.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
mindfulness.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

mindfulness.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
mindfulness.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

mindfulness.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

mindfulness.title: Acchariyaabbhuta sutta - Wonderful and Marvelous
mindfulness.description: Venerable Ānanda recollects the wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Tathāgata, the Buddha, relating to his conception and birth. The Buddha then caps it off by sharing what he considers the most wonderful and marvelous quality of all.

mindfulness.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
mindfulness.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

mindfulness.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
mindfulness.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

mindfulness.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
mindfulness.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

mindfulness.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
mindfulness.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

mindfulness.title: Sikkhānisaṁsa sutta - With Training as Benefit
mindfulness.description: The Buddha advises to live with training as the benefit, wisdom as the north star, liberation as the essence, ruled by mindfulness.

mindfulness.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
mindfulness.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

mindfulness.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
mindfulness.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

mindfulness.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
mindfulness.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

mindfulness.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
mindfulness.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

mindfulness.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
mindfulness.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

mindfulness.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
mindfulness.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

mindfulness.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
mindfulness.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

mindfulness.title: Ādhipateyya sutta - Authorities
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains the three guiding authorities for developing wholesome qualities and maintaining purity - 1) Oneself, 2) world, and 3) Dhamma.

mindfulness.title: Amata vagga - The Chapter On The Deathless
mindfulness.description: The Buddha explains the importance of mindfulness of the body in partaking in the deathless.

mindfulness.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
mindfulness.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

non-harm.title: Piyatara sutta - Dearer
non-harm.description: King Pasenadi of Kosala and Queen Mallikā discuss who is dearer to them.

non-harm.title: Subhāsita sutta - Well Spoken
non-harm.description: The Buddha explains the four qualities of speech that is well-spoken - 1) speaking only what is well spoken, 2) speaking only the Dhamma, 3) speaking only what is pleasing, and 4) speaking only the truth. The Venerable Vaṅgīsa then praises the Buddha's teaching with verses on the nature of well-spoken speech.

non-harm.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
non-harm.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

non-harm.title: Sanidāna sutta - From A Cause
non-harm.description: The Buddha explains how thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming arise from a cause and how to abandon them.

non-harm.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
non-harm.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

non-harm.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
non-harm.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

non-harm.title: Devadatta sutta - Devadatta
non-harm.description: The Buddha explains how Devadatta, overcome by evil desires, bad friendship, and abandoning the training, fell to Avīci hell. Though once esteemed, his envy led to ruin. The wise should associate with those whose path leads to the end of suffering.

non-harm.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding
non-harm.description: The three unwholesome thoughts are blinding, produce lack of clarity, cause ignorance, obstruct wisdom, and are troublesome and not conducive to Nibbāna. The three wholesome thoughts give sight, produce clarity and create insight, grow wisdom, and are trouble-free and conducive to Nibbāna.

non-harm.title: Putta sutta - Child
non-harm.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

non-harm.title: Moneyya sutta - Sagacity
non-harm.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of sagacity - by body, speech and mind.

non-harm.title: Soceyya sutta - Purity
non-harm.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of purity - by body, speech and mind.

non-harm.title: Sucarita sutta - Good Conduct
non-harm.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of good conduct - by body, speech and mind.

non-harm.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
non-harm.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

non-harm.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
non-harm.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

non-harm.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
non-harm.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

non-harm.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
non-harm.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

non-harm.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
non-harm.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

non-harm.title: Mettā sutta - Loving-Kindness
non-harm.description: Eight benefits of cultivating loving-kindness from sleeping with ease to fire, poison, and weapons not harming one to going to the Brahma world.

non-harm.title: Mettā sutta - Loving-Kindness
non-harm.description: 11 benefits of cultivating loving-kindness from sleeping with ease to dying unconfused to going to the Brahma world.

non-harm.title: Adanta vagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
non-harm.description: Short teachings contrasting the untamed and the tamed mind.

non-proliferation.title: Uraga sutta - Serpent
non-proliferation.description: Verses depicting the path to liberation through the central metaphor of a serpent shedding its skin. Each stanza illustrates how a bhikkhu abandons defilements like anger, passion, craving, and conceit, thereby casting off attachment to this world and the next.

non-proliferation.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
non-proliferation.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

one-pointedness.title: Chandasamādhi sutta - Collectedness Arising From Aspiration
one-pointedness.description: An analysis of the four bases of psychic powers that are endowed with collectedness arising from aspiration, determination, purification of mind, and investigation.

one-pointedness.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
