The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

one-pointedness.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
one-pointedness.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

one-pointedness.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
one-pointedness.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

one-pointedness.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
one-pointedness.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

one-pointedness.title: Ādhipateyya sutta - Authorities
one-pointedness.description: The Buddha explains the three guiding authorities for developing wholesome qualities and maintaining purity - 1) Oneself, 2) world, and 3) Dhamma.

one-pointedness.title: Paṁsudhovaka sutta - The Dirt Rinser
one-pointedness.description: The Buddha uses the gradual purification of gold as a metaphor for mental cultivation through meditation. Just as a goldsmith removes coarse, medium, and subtle impurities until the gold is workable and radiant, a meditator abandons defilements in stages. This gradual refinement leads to deep collectedness of mind, forming the foundation for supernormal abilities and, ultimately, liberation.

patience.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
patience.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

patience.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

patience.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha
patience.description: DhammaPada verses 179-196 describe the boundless and traceless nature of the Buddha, the teachings of all the Buddhas, rarity of a human birth, rarity of the arising of a Buddha, what is a safe refuge that leads to release from suffering, and the merit gained by ones who honor the Buddhas or their disciples.

patience.title: Akkhama sutta - Unable to Endure
patience.description: Using the example of a king’s elephant on the battlefield, the Buddha presents two contrasting scenarios - In one case, a person, overwhelmed by enticing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches is unable to collect and settle the mind; in the other, a person patiently endures without becoming infatuated with external objects, and is able to compose and stabilize the mind amidst sensory contact.

politeness.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
politeness.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

politeness.title: Paṭhamaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (First)
politeness.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) diligence, and 6) courteousness. The Buddha affirms these qualities as supportive of progress toward Nibbāna.

politeness.title: Vācā sutta - Speech
politeness.description: Five factors of well-spoken speech are - 1) It is spoken at the proper time, 2) truthfully, 3) gently, 4) in a way that benefits, and 5) spoken with a mind of loving-kindness.

quenching.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
quenching.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

quenching.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
quenching.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

quenching.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
quenching.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

recognition of impermanence.title: Avijjāpahāna sutta - Abandoning Ignorance
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha teaches on how to know and see the impermanence of the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception for the abandoning of ignorance and the arising of wisdom.

recognition of impermanence.title: Ajjhatta sutta - Internal
recognition of impermanence.description: By clinging to the five aggregates, one experiences pleasure and pain.

recognition of impermanence.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

recognition of impermanence.title: Dutiyadasabala sutta - Ten Powers (Second)
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha, endowed with the ten powers and four assurances, reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising. He then urges the bhikkhus to practice with diligence for their highest welfare as well as for the welfare of others.

recognition of impermanence.title: Dasabala sutta - Ten Powers
recognition of impermanence.description: Endowed with ten powers and four assurances, the Buddha reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising.

recognition of impermanence.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

recognition of impermanence.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
recognition of impermanence.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

recognition of impermanence.title: Bhidura sutta - Fragile
recognition of impermanence.description: The body is fragile, consciousness is of a fading nature. All substrates of existence are impermanent, dissatisfactory, and subject to change.

recognition of impermanence.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
recognition of impermanence.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

recognition of impermanence.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
recognition of impermanence.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

recognition of impermanence.title: Jarā vagga - Chapter 11 - Old Age
recognition of impermanence.description: Dhammapada verses 146–156 explore impermanence, the nature of the body, and the inevitability of aging and death. Through metaphors of a world ablaze, a decaying body, the house-builder and a city of bones, they point to life's transience and the futility of clinging to sensual pleasures. The verses highlight the cultivation of wisdom, detachment, and the pursuit of an unconditioned state beyond constructs, contrasting fleeting youth and inevitable old age with the timeless teachings that lead to liberation.

recognition of impermanence.title: Sahassavagga - Chapter 8 - One Thousand
recognition of impermanence.description: Dhammapada verses 100-115 share the importance of one teaching that brings peace, the benefits of self-conquest, the value of honoring the awakened, and the importance of rousing of energy and recognizing impermanence.

recognition of not-self.title: Ānanda sutta - With Ānanda
recognition of not-self.description: When the venerable Ānanda wishes to go for a solitary retreat, the Buddha teaches him to contemplate the five aggregates subject to appropriation and being assumed as one's self.

recognition of not-self.title: Ajjhatta sutta - Internal
recognition of not-self.description: By clinging to the five aggregates, one experiences pleasure and pain.

recognition of not-self.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
recognition of not-self.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

recognition of not-self.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
recognition of not-self.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

recognition of not-self.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
recognition of not-self.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

recognition of unattractiveness.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
recognition of unattractiveness.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

recognition of unattractiveness.title: Jarā vagga - Chapter 11 - Old Age
recognition of unattractiveness.description: Dhammapada verses 146–156 explore impermanence, the nature of the body, and the inevitability of aging and death. recognition of unattractiveness.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
recognition of unattractiveness.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

recollection of the Buddha.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
recollection of the Buddha.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

recollection of the Buddha.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
recollection of the Buddha.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

recollection of the Buddha.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha
recollection of the Buddha.description: DhammaPada verses 179-196 describe the boundless and traceless nature of the Buddha, the teachings of all the Buddhas, rarity of a human birth, rarity of the arising of a Buddha, what is a safe refuge that leads to release from suffering, and the merit gained by ones who honor the Buddhas or their disciples.

recollection of the Buddha.title: Vesārajja sutta - Assurances
recollection of the Buddha.description: The Buddha describes the four assurances possessed by the Tathāgata.

recollection of death.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
recollection of death.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

recollection of death.title: Jarā vagga - Chapter 11 - Old Age
recollection of death.description: Dhammapada verses 146–156 explore impermanence, the nature of the body, and the inevitability of aging and death. Through metaphors of a world ablaze, a decaying body, the house-builder and a city of bones, they point to life's transience and the futility of clinging to sensual pleasures. The verses highlight the cultivation of wisdom, detachment, and the pursuit of an unconditioned state beyond constructs, contrasting fleeting youth and inevitable old age with the timeless teachings that lead to liberation.

recollection of death.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
recollection of death.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

recollection of death.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
recollection of death.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

recollection of death.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
recollection of death.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

respect.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
respect.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

respect.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
respect.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

respect.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
respect.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

respect.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
respect.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

respect.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
respect.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

respect.title: Sakkāra sutta - Respect
respect.description: The Blessed One describes how beings are affected by respect and disrespect, and how this affects their rebirth. The true person is one who is collected, detached, and delights in the ending of grasping.

respect.title: Sabrahmaka sutta - With Brahmā
respect.description: Where children honor their mother and father, those families are said to dwell with Brahmā.

respect.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
respect.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

respect.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha

respect.title: Sahassavagga - Chapter 8 - One Thousand
respect.description: Dhammapada verses 100-115 share the importance of one teaching that brings peace, the benefits of self-conquest, the value of honoring the awakened, and the importance of rousing of energy and recognizing impermanence.

respect.title: Dutiyaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (Second)
respect.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) conscience, and 6) moral dread. The Buddha confirms these as conditions for stability and progress on the path.

respect.title: Paṭhamaaparihānasutta - Non-decline (First)
respect.description: A radiant deity visits the Buddha and shares six qualities that ensure the non-decline of a bhikkhu - 1) respect for the Teacher, 2) the Dhamma, 3) the Saṅgha, 4) the training, 5) diligence, and 6) courteousness. The Buddha affirms these qualities as supportive of progress toward Nibbāna.

respect.title: Paṭhama uruvela sutta - Uruvelā (First)
respect.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

respect.title: Sabrahmaka sutta - With Brahmā
respect.description: Where children honor their mother and father, those families are said to dwell with Brahmā.

right effort.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
right effort.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

right effort.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty
right effort.description: The Buddha expounds the noble right collectedness complete with its supporting conditions, clarifying how the factors of the noble eightfold path give rise to either mundane or supramundane fruits. He shows how right view leads to the sequential development of the path, culminating in right knowledge and right liberation.

right effort.title: Cara sutta - Walking
right effort.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

right effort.title: Cara sutta - Walking
right effort.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

right speech.title: Subhāsita sutta - Well Spoken
right speech.description: The Buddha explains the four qualities of speech that is well-spoken - 1) speaking only what is well spoken, 2) speaking only the Dhamma, 3) speaking only what is pleasing, and 4) speaking only the truth. The Venerable Vaṅgīsa then praises the Buddha's teaching with verses on the nature of well-spoken speech.

right speech.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
right speech.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

right speech.title: Attarakkhita sutta - Self-Protection
right speech.description: Even if protected by an entire army, one who engages in misconduct is unprotected. But one who engages in good conduct protects themselves, even without external protection.

right speech.title: Paṭhama kassapa sutta - Kassapa (First)
right speech.description: The young deity Kassapa, on Buddha's invitation, shares a verse on the instruction for a bhikkhu.

right speech.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
right speech.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

right speech.title: Paṭhama parihāni sutta - Decline (First)
right speech.description: The Buddha explains seven things that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and seven things that do not.

right speech.title: Vācā sutta - Speech
right speech.description: Five factors of well-spoken speech are - 1) It is spoken at the proper time, 2) truthfully, 3) gently, 4) in a way that benefits, and 5) spoken with a mind of loving-kindness.

right speech.title: Pasādakaradhamma vagga - Qualities Inspiring Confidence
right speech.description: The Buddha shares qualities that inspire confidence in the spiritual life.

right view.title: Uddhata sutta - Restless
right view.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance about the qualities of a person who falls under the sway of Māra and of one who overcomes all bad destinations.

right view.title: Mogharājamāṇavapucchā - Mogharāja’s Question
right view.description: The venerable Mogharāja asks the Buddha how to look upon the world so that the King of Death does not see one. The Buddha advises to look upon the world as empty, being ever mindful, and to uproot the sense of self.

right view.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

right view.title: Māgaṇḍiya sutta - To Māgaṇḍiya
right view.description: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya holds the view that sensual indulgence is spiritual growth and harshly criticizes the Buddha for teaching sense restraint, calling him a destroyer of spiritual growth. The Buddha skilfully reveals the true nature of sensual pleasures through vivid similes such as a leper finding relief by scorching himself over burning coals and a blind man mistaking a filthy rag for a spotless white cloth.

right view.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
right view.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

right view.title: Mahācattārīsaka sutta - The Great Forty

right view.description: DhammaPada verses 33-43 share about the nature of the mind, the drawbacks of an untamed mind, and the benefits of protecting and restraining the mind. right view.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
right view.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

right view.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
right view.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

right view.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
right view.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

rousing of energy.title: Dutiyadasabala sutta - Ten Powers (Second)
rousing of energy.description: The Buddha, endowed with the ten powers and four assurances, reveals the impermanence of the five aggregates and teaches dependent co-arising. He then urges the bhikkhus to practice with diligence for their highest welfare as well as for the welfare of others.

rousing of energy.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

rousing of energy.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

rousing of energy.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
rousing of energy.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

rousing of energy.title: Tevijja sutta - Possessing the Threefold Knowledge

This includes the recollection of past lives, the divine eye seeing beings’ rebirths according to kamma, and the realization of liberation through the wearing away of mental defilements.

rousing of energy.title: Dhātusosaṁsandana sutta - The Coming Together of Elements

rousing of energy.description: The Buddha explains the three guiding authorities for developing wholesome qualities and maintaining purity - 1) Oneself, 2) world, and 3) Dhamma.

rousing of energy.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

sense restraint.description: The Buddha explains how there is non-restraint and restraint with a simile of six animals with different domains and feeding grounds. He uses strong post or pillar as a designation for mindfulness directed to the body.

sense restraint.title: Udāyī sutta - With Udāyī
sense restraint.description: The venerable Udāyī asks the venerable Ānanda about how to see the not-self nature of consciousness.

sense restraint.title: Bāḷisikopama sutta - The Fisherman's Simile
sense restraint.description: The Buddha likens the six types of desirable sense objects to baited hooks, set in the world for the misfortune of beings—those who cling to them fall under Māra’s power.

sense restraint.title: Paṭhama samudda sutta - Ocean (First)
sense restraint.description: The Buddha uses the simile of an ocean to describe the six sense bases and their respective objects.

sense restraint.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
sense restraint.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

sense restraint.title: Sakkapañha sutta - Sakka's Question
sense restraint.description: The Buddha answers Sakka's question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very life.

sense restraint.title: Attarakkhita sutta - Self-Protection
sense restraint.description: Even if protected by an entire army, one who engages in misconduct is unprotected. But one who engages in good conduct protects themselves, even without external protection.

sense restraint.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
sense restraint.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

sense restraint.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
sense restraint.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

sense restraint.title: Atta vagga - Chapter 12 - Self
sense restraint.description: Dhammapada verses 157-166 emphasize self-discipline, personal responsibility, and inner mastery. A wise person must first establish themselves properly before guiding others, as self-mastery is difficult but essential. Purity and impurity are personal matters, and one should prioritize their own spiritual welfare over external concerns, for no one can purify another.

sense restraint.title: Paṭhama parihāni sutta - Decline (First)
sense restraint.description: The Buddha explains seven things that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and seven things that do not.

sincerity.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
sincerity.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

sincerity.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
sincerity.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

solitude.title: Paṭhama kassapa sutta - Kassapa (First)
solitude.description: The young deity Kassapa, on Buddha's invitation, shares a verse on the instruction for a bhikkhu.

solitude.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
solitude.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

solitude.title: Mahāassapura sutta - The Greater Discourse at Assapura
solitude.description: The Buddha outlines a progressive training guideline for the bhikkhus to undertake in order to be recognized as ascetics and Brahmins. The Buddha also describes the abandonment of the five hindrances, the four jhānas, and the three knowledges using similes.

solitude.title: Paṭisallāna sutta - Seclusion
solitude.description: The Buddha instructs to dwell in seclusion, enjoying solitude, being devoted to tranquility of mind, meditating with diligence, being endowed with discernment, practicing in an empty dwelling.

solitude.title: Bāla vagga - Chapter 5 - Immature
solitude.description: DhammaPada verses 60-75 describe the traits and consequences for an immature person. They suffer from delusion, cling to false views of self and possessions, perform harmful actions, seek status without wisdom, and long for recognition. In contrast, the wise avoid their company and pursue seclusion and true understanding of the Dhamma.

solitude.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
solitude.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

solitude.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
solitude.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

solitude.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
solitude.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

solitude.title: Sukha vagga - Chapter 15 - Happiness
solitude.description: DhammaPada verses 197-208 describe the happiness of those who live without hatred, affliction, and anxiety. It includes poetic verses on happiness and Nibbāna, and emphasizes seeing, dwelling, and association with the wise, noble ones.

solitude.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
solitude.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

solitude.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
solitude.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

solitude.title: Ādhipateyya sutta - Authorities
solitude.description: The Buddha explains the three guiding authorities for developing wholesome qualities and maintaining purity - 1) Oneself, 2) world, and 3) Dhamma.

sorrow-free.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
sorrow-free.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

sorrow-free.title: Arahanta vagga - Chapter 7 - The Awakened Being
sorrow-free.description: Dhammapada verses 90-99 describe the qualities and conduct of the Arahant, a fully awakened being who has reached the end of the path. Free from defilements and clinging, their actions leave no trace, like birds in the sky. At peace and delighting in solitude, wherever they dwell becomes a place of beauty.

sorrow-free.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
sorrow-free.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

sorrow-free.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
sorrow-free.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

sorrow-free.title: Andha sutta - Blind
sorrow-free.description: The Buddha describes three types of people - the blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

tame.title: Loka sutta - World
tame.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

tame.title: Arahanta vagga - Chapter 7 - The Awakened Being
tame.description: Dhammapada verses 90-99 describe the qualities and conduct of the Arahant, a fully awakened being who has reached the end of the path. Free from defilements and clinging, their actions leave no trace, like birds in the sky. At peace and delighting in solitude, wherever they dwell becomes a place of beauty.

tame.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
tame.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

tame.title: Citta vagga - Chapter 3 - Mind
tame.description: DhammaPada verses 33-43 share about the nature of the mind, the drawbacks of an untamed mind, and the benefits of protecting and restraining the mind. Those who restrain the mind will be freed from the shackles of death. Not even one's own mother, father, or any other relatives can do as much good as a rightly oriented mind can.

tame.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
tame.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

tame.title: Atta vagga - Chapter 12 - Self
tame.description: Dhammapada verses 157-166 emphasize self-discipline, personal responsibility, and inner mastery. A wise person must first establish themselves properly before guiding others, as self-mastery is difficult but essential. Purity and impurity are personal matters, and one should prioritize their own spiritual welfare over external concerns, for no one can purify another.

tame.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
tame.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

tame.title: Adanta vagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
tame.description: Short teachings contrasting the untamed and the tamed mind.

tranquility.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
tranquility.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

tranquility.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
tranquility.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

tranquility.title: Paṭhama kassapa sutta - Kassapa (First)
tranquility.description: The young deity Kassapa, on Buddha's invitation, shares a verse on the instruction for a bhikkhu.

tranquility.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

tranquility.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

tranquility.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
tranquility.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

tranquility.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
tranquility.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

tranquility.title: Devadatta sutta - Devadatta
tranquility.description: The Buddha explains how Devadatta, overcome by evil desires, bad friendship, and abandoning the training, fell to Avīci hell. Though once esteemed, his envy led to ruin. The wise should associate with those whose path leads to the end of suffering.

tranquility.title: Dhammānudhammapaṭipanna sutta - Practicing in Accordance with the Dhamma
tranquility.description: It is natural for a practitioner practicing in accordance with the Dhamma to speak and think only in terms of the Dhamma, not in terms of what is not the Dhamma.

tranquility.title: Santatara sutta - More Peaceful than
tranquility.description: The formless existence is more peaceful than the form realm. Yet, cessation is more peaceful than the formless existence.

tranquility.title: Indriya sutta - Mental Faculties
tranquility.description: The Buddha describes the three mental faculties - the faculty that senses ‘I will know the unknown,’ the faculty of awakening, and the faculty of one who is awakened.

tranquility.title: Paṭisallāna sutta - Seclusion
tranquility.description: The Buddha instructs to dwell in seclusion, enjoying solitude, being devoted to tranquility of mind, meditating with diligence, being endowed with discernment, practicing in an empty dwelling.

tranquility.title: Loka sutta - World
tranquility.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

tranquility.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
tranquility.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

tranquility.title: Arahanta vagga - Chapter 7 - The Awakened Being

tranquility.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
tranquility.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

tranquility.title: Paṭhama vagga - First Subchapter On One Thing
tranquility.description: The Buddha shares the importance of recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, Saṅgha, one's virtue, generosity, deities, in-and-out breathing, death, body, and peace.

tranquility.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
tranquility.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

truth.title: Subhāsita sutta - Well Spoken
truth.description: The Buddha explains the four qualities of speech that is well-spoken - 1) speaking only what is well spoken, 2) speaking only the Dhamma, 3) speaking only what is pleasing, and 4) speaking only the truth. The Venerable Vaṅgīsa then praises the Buddha's teaching with verses on the nature of well-spoken speech.

truth.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
truth.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

truth.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
truth.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

truth.title: Vācā sutta - Speech
truth.description: Five factors of well-spoken speech are - 1) It is spoken at the proper time, 2) truthfully, 3) gently, 4) in a way that benefits, and 5) spoken with a mind of loving-kindness.

unassuming.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
unassuming.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

unassuming.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
unassuming.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

imperturbable.title: Uraga sutta - Serpent
imperturbable.description: Verses depicting the path to liberation through the central metaphor of a serpent shedding its skin. Each stanza illustrates how a bhikkhu abandons defilements like anger, passion, craving, and conceit, thereby casting off attachment to this world and the next.

imperturbable.title: Upaya sutta - Attachment
imperturbable.description: Consciousness, while persisting, might persist attached to form, feeling, perception, and intentional constructions. When passion for these is abandoned, the support for the establishment of consciousness is completely cut off. That consciousness, being unestablished, does not grow, and by not intentionally constructing, is liberated.

imperturbable.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
imperturbable.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. imperturbable.title: Upaparikkha sutta - Examining
imperturbable.description: The Buddha instructs that one should examine experience in such a way that consciousness does not become scattered among external sense objects, fixated internally, or entangled through grasping.

imperturbable.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
imperturbable.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

imperturbable.title: Pañcapubbanimitta sutta - Five Preceding Signs
imperturbable.description: The Buddha describes the five signs that appear when a deity is about to pass away, and the three blessings that the gods give to the deity.

imperturbable.title: Sampannasīla sutta - Virtuous
imperturbable.description: The Buddha describes the further training guideline on how to practice the Dhamma while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down for bhikkhus who are virtuous, and accomplished in the moral code of conduct.

imperturbable.title: Niraya vagga - Chapter 22 - Hell
imperturbable.description: Dhammapada verses 306–319 warn of the suffering that follows false speech, misconduct, and wrong view. The verses highlight the danger of negligence, hypocrisy, and slack effort in spiritual practice. Those who cultivate right view, ethical conduct, and firm effort attain a good destination, while those who embrace wrong views and harmful actions fall into misery.

imperturbable.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted

vigour.title: Chandasamādhi sutta - Collectedness Arising From Aspiration
vigour.description: An analysis of the four bases of psychic powers that are endowed with collectedness arising from aspiration, determination, purification of mind, and investigation.

vigour.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
vigour.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

vigour.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
vigour.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

vigour.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
vigour.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. vigour.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
vigour.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

vigour.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
vigour.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

vigour.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
vigour.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

vigour.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
vigour.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

vision.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
vision.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

vision.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma

vision.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

vision.title: Ekapuggala vagga - The Chapter On One Person
vision.description: The Buddha describes the unique qualities of the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the perfectly Awakened One.
