wholesome.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

wholesome.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
wholesome.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

wholesome.title: Putta sutta - Child
wholesome.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

wholesome.title: Paṇḍita vagga - Chapter 6 - The Wise
wholesome.description: DhammaPada verses 76-89 share on associating with a wise person, characteristics of such a person, the importance of joy in the Dhamma, the benefits of renunciation, and the qualities of a well cultivated mind.

wholesome.title: Loka vagga - Chapter 13 - World
wholesome.description: Dhammapada verses 167-178 emphasize living in accordance with the Dhamma, avoiding negligence, not embrace wrong view, and not indulging in the world. One should rise up, live with good conduct, and not live with unwholesome conduct. The world is blind, and only a few see clearly. Swans travel the pathway of the sun, and the wise are emancipated from the world.

wholesome.title: Atta vagga - Chapter 12 - Self
wholesome.description: Dhammapada verses 157-166 emphasize self-discipline, personal responsibility, and inner mastery. A wise person must first establish themselves properly before guiding others, as self-mastery is difficult but essential. Purity and impurity are personal matters, and one should prioritize their own spiritual welfare over external concerns, for no one can purify another.

wholesome.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
wholesome.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

wholesome.title: Dutiya dāna sutta - Giving (Second)
wholesome.description: Wholesome giving along with faith and a sense of right and wrong is the way of practice that leads to the world of gods.

wholesome.title: Vitthāra sutta - Kamma in Detail
wholesome.description: The Buddha describes the four kinds of kamma (actions) and their results in detail.

wholesome.title: Saṅkhitta sutta - Kamma in Brief
wholesome.description: The Buddha describes the four kinds of kamma (actions) and their results in brief.

wholesome.title: Andha sutta - Blind
wholesome.description: The Buddha describes three types of people - the blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

wholesome.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
wholesome.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

wholesome.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
wholesome.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

wholesome.title: Adhamma vagga - The Chapter On Not The Teaching
wholesome.description: The Buddha shares the importance of explaining correctly what is not the Dhamma, Vinaya, spoken or uttered, practiced, and prescribed by the Tathāgata.

wisdom.title: Upāsaka sutta - Lay Disciple
wisdom.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance contrasting one who has comprehended the nature of reality with one who is with possessions.

wisdom.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
wisdom.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Subhāsita sutta - Well Spoken
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains the four qualities of speech that is well-spoken - 1) speaking only what is well spoken, 2) speaking only the Dhamma, 3) speaking only what is pleasing, and 4) speaking only the truth. The Venerable Vaṅgīsa then praises the Buddha's teaching with verses on the nature of well-spoken speech.

wisdom.title: Uṭṭhāna sutta - Rise Up
wisdom.description: Verses urging one to rise from negligence, train steadfastly for the state of peace, and not waste the fleeting opportunity of the present moment. The teaching emphasizes the urgency of effort with the imagery of the afflicted pierced by a dart and the King of Death misleading one who remains negligent.

wisdom.title: Jaṭā sutta - Knot
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains how the tangle of defilements can be disentangled through the practice of virtue, meditation, and wisdom.

wisdom.title: Gārava sutta - Respect
wisdom.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Vibhaṅga sutta - Analysis
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains in detail each factor of the noble eightfold path—right view, right intention, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right collectedness.

wisdom.title: Avijjāpahāna sutta - Abandoning Ignorance
wisdom.description: The Buddha teaches on how to know and see the impermanence of the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception for the abandoning of ignorance and the arising of wisdom.

wisdom.title: Bāḷisikopama sutta - The Fisherman's Simile
wisdom.description: The Buddha likens the six types of desirable sense objects to baited hooks, set in the world for the misfortune of beings—those who cling to them fall under Māra’s power.

wisdom.title: Paṭhama samudda sutta - Ocean (First)
wisdom.description: The Buddha uses the simile of an ocean to describe the six sense bases and their respective objects.

wisdom.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
wisdom.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

wisdom.title: Sakkapañha sutta - Sakka's Question
wisdom.description: The Buddha answers Sakka's question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very life.

wisdom.title: Rādha sutta - Rādha
wisdom.description: The Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha on how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies to self-identification, possessiveness, and conceit cease to arise.

wisdom.title: Anattalakkhaṇa sutta - Characteristic of Being Not-self
wisdom.description: After examining the impermanence, unsatisfactoriness, and the changing nature of the five aggregates, the Buddha teaches how to see them with proper wisdom, as not being suitable to identify with.

wisdom.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
wisdom.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

wisdom.title: Anāthapiṇḍika sutta - Anāthapiṇḍika
wisdom.description: Household Anāthapiṇḍika, after passing away, appears as a young deity and recites verses to the Buddha on the value of thoroughly examining the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Subha sutta - With Subha
wisdom.description: The young brahmin Subha questions the Buddha about whether householders or renunciants are superior and what brings the greatest merit. The Buddha explains that he evaluates actions with discernment, and then teaches the path to companionship with Brahmā through cultivation of the qualities of loving-kindness, compassion, appreciative joy, and equanimity.

wisdom.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
wisdom.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

wisdom.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
wisdom.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

wisdom.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
wisdom.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

wisdom.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

wisdom.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
wisdom.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

wisdom.title: Ānāpānassati sutta - Mindfulness while Breathing In and Out
wisdom.description: The Buddha teaches in detail how to develop mindfulness while breathing in and out through sixteen naturally unfolding steps, showing how their cultivation fulfills the four establishments of mindfulness, which in turn fulfill the seven factors of awakening, culminating in true knowledge and liberation.

wisdom.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
wisdom.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

wisdom.title: Kalyāṇasīla sutta - Virtuous Conduct
wisdom.description: The Buddha defines the perfected person as one who is virtuous in conduct, devoted to the cultivation of the seven sets of qualities that lead to awakening, and possessing wisdom of the ending of suffering—complete in training and free from the mental defilements.

wisdom.title: Kāmūpapatti sutta - Rebirths in the Sensual Realm
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes three kinds of beings who partake in sensual pleasures - 1) those who enjoy what is presently available, 2) those who delight in their own creations, and 3) those who wield power over the creations of others.

wisdom.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

wisdom.title: Dhātusosaṁsandana sutta - The Coming Together of Elements
wisdom.description: Beings come together and associate with other beings according to their disposition. Therefore, one should avoid associating with those that are lazy and keep company with the wise.

wisdom.title: Sikkhānisaṁsa sutta - With Training as Benefit
wisdom.description: The Buddha advises to live with training as the benefit, wisdom as the north star, liberation as the essence, ruled by mindfulness.

wisdom.title: Paññāparihīna sutta - Lacking in Wisdom
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the sentient beings who lack in wisdom as truly deprived, dwelling in suffering, annoyance, hardship, and distress.

wisdom.title: Sīlasampanna sutta - Accomplished in Virtue
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the benefits of associating with bhikkhus who are accomplished in virtue, collectedness, wisdom, liberation, and the knowledge and vision of liberation.

wisdom.title: Samaṇabrāhmaṇa sutta - Ascetics and Brahmins
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the true ascetic and brahmin as one who understands the four noble truths.

wisdom.title: Paṇḍita vagga - Chapter 6 - The Wise
wisdom.description: DhammaPada verses 76-89 share on associating with a wise person, characteristics of such a person, the importance of joy in the Dhamma, the benefits of renunciation, and the qualities of a well cultivated mind.

wisdom.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
wisdom.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

wisdom.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

wisdom.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

wisdom.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

wisdom.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

wisdom.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

wisdom.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
wisdom.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

wisdom.title: Loka vagga - Chapter 13 - World
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 167-178 emphasize living in accordance with the Dhamma, avoiding negligence, not embrace wrong view, and not indulging in the world. One should rise up, live with good conduct, and not live with unwholesome conduct. The world is blind, and only a few see clearly. Swans travel the pathway of the sun, and the wise are emancipated from the world.

wisdom.title: Jarā vagga - Chapter 11 - Old Age
wisdom.description: Dhammapada verses 146–156 explore impermanence, the nature of the body, and the inevitability of aging and death. Through metaphors of a world ablaze, a decaying body, the house-builder and a city of bones, they point to life's transience and the futility of clinging to sensual pleasures. The verses highlight the cultivation of wisdom, detachment, and the pursuit of an unconditioned state beyond constructs, contrasting fleeting youth and inevitable old age with the timeless teachings that lead to liberation.

wisdom.title: Paṭhamahatthaka sutta - With Hatthaka (First)
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven wonderful and marvelous qualities of the householder Hatthaka of Āḷavī. When he learns about this from a certain bhikkhu, Hatthaka is concerned if any other householder heard the praise. Learning of this, the Buddha adds contentment as the eighth wonderful and marvelous quality of Hatthaka.

wisdom.title: Ugga sutta - Ugga
wisdom.description: Migāra of Rohaṇa is a wealthy man, but even his riches are vulnerable to the vicissitudes of life, unlike the seven kinds of wealth the Buddha describes which cannot be taken away.

wisdom.title: Vitthatadhana sutta - Wealth in Detail
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in detail, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom. One who possesses these is not truly poor, and their life is not lived in vain.

wisdom.title: Saṅkhittadhana sutta - Wealth in Brief
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven kinds of wealth in brief, of 1) faith, 2) virtue, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) learning, 6) generosity, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Vitthatabala sutta - Powers in Detail
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in detail, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Saṅkhittabala sutta - Powers in Brief
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the seven powers in brief, of 1) faith, 2) energy, 3) conscience, 4) fear of wrongdoing, 5) mindfulness, 6) collectedness, and 7) wisdom.

wisdom.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
wisdom.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

wisdom.title: Bhojana sutta - Food
wisdom.description: The giver of food gives five things to the recipients - life, beauty, happiness, strength, and eloquence. They also find happiness as a result of their giving.

wisdom.title: Paṭhama uruvela sutta - Uruvelā (First)
wisdom.description: The Buddha reflects on who he should honor and respect after his full awakening. Brahmā Sahampati encourages him to honor and respect the Dhamma.

wisdom.title: Vibhatti sutta - Analytical Knowledges
wisdom.description: Venerable Sāriputta describes the four analytical knowledges he realized a half-month after his full ordination.

wisdom.title: Ātappakaraṇīya sutta - Vigour
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes three cases where vigour should be applied.

wisdom.title: Paṭicchanna sutta - Obscured
wisdom.description: Three things thrive when obscured, not when exposed. And three things that shine forth when exposed, not when obscured.

wisdom.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
wisdom.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

wisdom.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
wisdom.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

wisdom.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
wisdom.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

wisdom.title: Aṭṭhāna vagga - The Chapter On The Impossible
wisdom.description: Short teachings on the impossibility of certain events, actions, or outcomes.

wisdom.title: Ekapuggala vagga - The Chapter On One Person
wisdom.description: The Buddha describes the unique qualities of the Tathāgata, the Arahant, the perfectly Awakened One.

wise attention.title: Rādha sutta - Rādha
wise attention.description: The Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha on how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies to self-identification, possessiveness, and conceit cease to arise.

wise attention.title: Nagara sutta - The City
wise attention.description: The Buddha recounts how he attained full awakening by examining the principle of dependent co-arising. He likens this realization to a man discovering an ancient, forgotten city.

wise attention.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
wise attention.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

wise attention.title: Niddasavatthu sutta - Grounds for Inclination
wise attention.description: The Buddha describes the seven grounds for wholesome inclinations, of 1) undertaking the training precepts, 2) attending carefully to the Dhamma, 3) removing longing, 4) seclusion, 5) arousing energy, 6) skilled mindfulness, and 7) realization of right view.

wise attention.title: Ādhipateyya sutta - Authorities
wise attention.description: The Buddha explains the three guiding authorities for developing wholesome qualities and maintaining purity - 1) Oneself, 2) world, and 3) Dhamma.

wise attention.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
wise attention.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

wise attention.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
wise attention.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

wise attention.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
wise attention.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

wise attention.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
wise attention.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

wise attention.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
wise attention.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

with nothing.title: Paṇḍita vagga - Chapter 6 - The Wise
with nothing.description: DhammaPada verses 76-89 share on associating with a wise person, characteristics of such a person, the importance of joy in the Dhamma, the benefits of renunciation, and the qualities of a well cultivated mind.

with nothing.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
with nothing.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

with nothing.title: Kodha vagga - Chapter 17 - Anger
with nothing.description: Dhammapada verses 221-234 emphasize abandoning anger, conceit, and mental defilements while cultivating restraint in body, speech, and mind. The verses highlight overcoming harmful actions by giving and speaking truth, the inevitability of criticism, and the value of moral discipline. Those intent on Nibbāna, ever watchful, and well-restrained are beyond reproach and honored even by the gods.

with nothing.title: Sukha vagga - Chapter 15 - Happiness
with nothing.description: DhammaPada verses 197-208 describe the happiness of those who live without hatred, affliction, and anxiety. It includes poetic verses on happiness and Nibbāna, and emphasizes seeing, dwelling, and association with the wise, noble ones.

without fear.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
without fear.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

without fear.title: Loka sutta - World
without fear.description: The Buddha explains why he is called the Tathāgata, the one who has perfectly understood the world, its arising, cessation, and the way of practice leading to its cessation.

without fear.title: Buddha vagga - Chapter 14 - Buddha
without fear.description: DhammaPada verses 179-196 describe the boundless and traceless nature of the Buddha, the teachings of all the Buddhas, rarity of a human birth, rarity of the arising of a Buddha, what is a safe refuge that leads to release from suffering, and the merit gained by ones who honor the Buddhas or their disciples.

adventurous.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
adventurous.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

adventurous.title: Niraya vagga - Chapter 22 - Hell
adventurous.description: Dhammapada verses 306–319 warn of the suffering that follows false speech, misconduct, and wrong view. The verses highlight the danger of negligence, hypocrisy, and slack effort in spiritual practice. Those who cultivate right view, ethical conduct, and firm effort attain a good destination, while those who embrace wrong views and harmful actions fall into misery.

adventurous.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
adventurous.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

adventurous.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
adventurous.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

adventurous.title: Adanta vagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
adventurous.description: Short teachings contrasting the untamed and the tamed mind.

aggressiveness.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
aggressiveness.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

aggressiveness.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
aggressiveness.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

aggressiveness.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
aggressiveness.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

aggressiveness.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
aggressiveness.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

aggressiveness.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
aggressiveness.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

attachment.title: Dutiyasatta sutta - Clinging (Second)
attachment.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on harm that comes from sensual desire.

attachment.title: Paṭhamasatta sutta - Clinging (First)
attachment.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi excessively clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on the bondage that ensues from sensual desire.

attachment.title: Visākhā sutta - Visākha
attachment.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance to Visākhā on how all under another's control brings suffering.

attachment.title: Upāsaka sutta - Lay Disciple
attachment.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance contrasting one who has comprehended the nature of reality with one who is with possessions.

attachment.title: Uṭṭhāna sutta - Rise Up
attachment.description: Verses urging one to rise from negligence, train steadfastly for the state of peace, and not waste the fleeting opportunity of the present moment. The teaching emphasizes the urgency of effort with the imagery of the afflicted pierced by a dart and the King of Death misleading one who remains negligent.

attachment.title: Jaṭā sutta - Knot
attachment.description: The Buddha explains how the tangle of defilements can be disentangled through the practice of virtue, meditation, and wisdom.

attachment.title: Upādānakkhandha sutta - Aggregates Subject to Clinging
attachment.description: The five aggregates that are subject to clinging - 1) form, 2) feeling, 3) perception, 4) intentional constructions, and 5) consciousness - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five aggregates that are subject to clinging.

attachment.title: Gantha sutta - Knots
attachment.description: The four knots of 1) craving, 2) ill will, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to the idea that 'This is the truth' are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these knots.

attachment.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
attachment.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

attachment.title: Bhadraka sutta - With Bhadraka
attachment.description: The Buddha explains to the headman Bhadraka the root cause of suffering through a direct and relatable inquiry. When Bhadraka admits to feeling sorrow when those he cares about are harmed, the Buddha skillfully reveals that such sorrow arises not from the events themselves but from one’s own attachment and desire.

attachment.title: Sabbupādānapariññā sutta - Complete Comprehension of All Clinging
attachment.description: The Buddha teaches the Dhamma for the complete comprehension of all clinging through seeing the dependent co-arising of feeling through the six sense bases.

attachment.title: Ayyikā sutta - Grandmother
attachment.description: King Pasenadi expresses deep sorrow over his grandmother's death. The Buddha teaches him that all beings, without exception, are subject to death and cannot escape it, likening it to a potter's pots that are all bound to break.

attachment.title: Upaya sutta - Attachment
attachment.description: Consciousness, while persisting, might persist attached to form, feeling, perception, and intentional constructions. When passion for these is abandoned, the support for the establishment of consciousness is completely cut off. That consciousness, being unestablished, does not grow, and by not intentionally constructing, is liberated.

attachment.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
attachment.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

attachment.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
attachment.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

attachment.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
attachment.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

attachment.title: Bhidura sutta - Fragile
attachment.description: The body is fragile, consciousness is of a fading nature. All substrates of existence are impermanent, dissatisfactory, and subject to change.

attachment.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
attachment.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

attachment.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
attachment.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

attachment.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
attachment.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

attachment.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
attachment.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

attachment.title: Dānavatthu sutta - Grounds for Giving
attachment.description: The Buddha describes eight motivations for giving, including giving out of desire, aversion, and fear.

attachment.title: Dutiyabandhana sutta - Bond (Second)
attachment.description: The Buddha describes the eight ways in which a man binds a woman.

attachment.title: Paṭhamabandhana sutta - Bond (First)
attachment.description: The Buddha describes the eight ways in which a woman binds a man.

anger.title: Dhanañjānī sutta - Dhanañjānī
anger.description: When a brahmin woman expresses faith in the Buddha, her husband, a brahmin of the Bhāradvāja clan, goes to dispute the doctrine of the Buddha. The Buddha teaches the brahmin the importance of cutting off anger.

anger.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
anger.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

anger.title: Māgha sutta - Māgha
anger.description: The young deity Māgha asks the Buddha in a verse on what to cut off to sleep with ease and grieve no more. The Buddha advises to cut off anger.

anger.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
anger.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

anger.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
anger.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

anger.title: Anaṅgaṇa sutta - Blemish Free
anger.description: Venerable Sāriputta explains the four kinds of persons based on their understanding of blemishes and blemish-free qualities. He uses the simile of a bronze bowl to illustrate the importance of understanding one's blemishes and blemish-free qualities.

anger.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
anger.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

anger.title: Cūḷadukkhakkhandha sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
anger.description: A lay disciple asks the Buddha why greed, aversion, and illusion still occupy and remain in his mind. The Buddha explains the importance of cultivating discernment of the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures along with cultivating the joy and happiness apart from sensual pleasures. He then recounts a conversation with the Nigaṇṭhas on this topic.

anger.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
anger.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

anger.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
anger.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

anger.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding
anger.description: The three unwholesome thoughts are blinding, produce lack of clarity, cause ignorance, obstruct wisdom, and are troublesome and not conducive to Nibbāna. The three wholesome thoughts give sight, produce clarity and create insight, grow wisdom, and are trouble-free and conducive to Nibbāna.

anger.title: Duccarita sutta - Misconduct
anger.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of misconduct - by body, speech and mind.

anger.title: Nadīsota sutta - River Current
anger.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a person carried downstream by a lovely and alluring river current to illustrate the painful results of craving and indulgence in the internal sense bases.

anger.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
anger.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

anger.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
anger.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

anger.title: Paṭhama dāna sutta - Giving (First)
anger.description: The Buddha explains eight kinds of giving, including giving out of fear, giving to maintain a good reputation, and giving to purify the mind.

anger.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
anger.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

aversion.title: Nīvaraṇa sutta - Hindrances
aversion.description: The five hindrances - 1) sensual desire, 2) ill will, 3) dullness and drowsiness, 4) restlessness and worry, and 5) doubt - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

aversion.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

aversion.title: Pariñña sutta - Full Understanding
aversion.description: The Buddha teaches the things to be fully understood and what full understanding is.

aversion.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
aversion.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

aversion.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

aversion.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
aversion.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

aversion.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
aversion.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

aversion.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
aversion.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

aversion.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
aversion.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

aversion.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
aversion.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. aversion.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
aversion.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

aversion.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
aversion.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

aversion.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
aversion.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

aversion.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
aversion.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

aversion.title: Dutiya rāga sutta - Passion (Second)
aversion.description: Whoever has let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is called one who has crossed beyond the ocean—with its waves, currents, whirlpools, lurking with fierce animals and monsters.

aversion.title: Paṭhama rāga sutta - Passion (First)
aversion.description: Whoever has not let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is said to be bound by Māra, ensnared by Māra's trap, at the mercy of the Evil One, and subject to his will.

aversion.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
aversion.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

aversion.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
aversion.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

aversion.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
aversion.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

aversion.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
aversion.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

aversion.title: Dānavatthu sutta - Grounds for Giving
aversion.description: The Buddha describes eight motivations for giving, including giving out of desire, aversion, and fear.

aversion.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
aversion.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

aversion.title: Paṭhamaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (First)
aversion.description: The Buddha describes the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance that are present in living beings.

aversion.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
aversion.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

aversion.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
aversion.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

anxiety.title: Uddhata sutta - Restless
anxiety.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance about the qualities of a person who falls under the sway of Māra and of one who overcomes all bad destinations.

anxiety.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
anxiety.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

anxiety.title: Salla sutta - Arrow
anxiety.description: The Buddha explains the difference between an uninstructed ordinary person and a learned noble disciple in how they experience pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings.

anxiety.title: Parihāna sutta - Decline
anxiety.description: The Buddha describes three qualities that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and three qualities that lead to non-decline.

anxiety.title: Citta vagga - Chapter 3 - Mind
anxiety.description: DhammaPada verses 33-43 share about the nature of the mind, the drawbacks of an untamed mind, and the benefits of protecting and restraining the mind. Those who restrain the mind will be freed from the shackles of death. Not even one's own mother, father, or any other relatives can do as much good as a rightly oriented mind can.

anxiety.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
anxiety.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

bad friendship.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
bad friendship.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

bad friendship.title: Devadatta sutta - Devadatta
bad friendship.description: The Buddha explains how Devadatta, overcome by evil desires, bad friendship, and abandoning the training, fell to Avīci hell. Though once esteemed, his envy led to ruin. The wise should associate with those whose path leads to the end of suffering.

bad friendship.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
bad friendship.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

bad friendship.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
bad friendship.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

bad friendship.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
bad friendship.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

bad habits.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
bad habits.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

bad habits.title: Kalyāṇamittādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Good Friendship
bad habits.description: The Buddha explains the importance of good friendship, the consequences of habitual engagement in unwholesome and wholesome qualities, wise and unwise attention, the loss or increase of relatives, wealth, and reputation contrasted with the loss or increase of wisdom.

boastfulness.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
boastfulness.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

conceit.title: Paṭhama dārukkhandhopama sutta - Simile of the Wooden Log (First)
conceit.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a log of wood carried by a river to explain the eight obstacles to reaching Nibbāna.

conceit.title: Rādha sutta - Rādha
conceit.description: The Venerable Rādha asks the Buddha on how to know and see so that the underlying tendencies to self-identification, possessiveness, and conceit cease to arise.

conceit.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
conceit.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

conceit.title: Verambha sutta - Turbulent
conceit.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of turbulent winds high in the sky.

conceit.title: Siṅgāla sutta - Jackal
conceit.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of an old jackal with mange.

conceit.title: Kumma sutta - The Turtle
conceit.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a turtle struck by a harpoon to illustrate how attachments to acquisitions, respect, and popularity can lead to misfortune and hinder spiritual progress.

conceit.title: Samiddhi sutta - With Samiddhi
conceit.description: A radiant deity tempts young Samiddhi to enjoy sensual pleasures. The Buddha later reveals that true liberation transcends identity and craving, and is only found by those who let go of even the need to describe themselves.

conceit.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
conceit.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

conceit.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
conceit.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

conceit.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
conceit.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

conceit.title: Anaṅgaṇa sutta - Blemish Free
conceit.description: Venerable Sāriputta explains the four kinds of persons based on their understanding of blemishes and blemish-free qualities. He uses the simile of a bronze bowl to illustrate the importance of understanding one's blemishes and blemish-free qualities.

conceit.title: Mahāsaccaka sutta - The Greater Discourse with Saccaka
conceit.description: The Buddha explains the difference between cultivation and lack of cultivation with regard to body and mind, and recounts his own journey to full awakening.

conceit.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
conceit.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

conceit.title: Devadatta sutta - Devadatta
conceit.description: The Buddha explains how Devadatta, overcome by evil desires, bad friendship, and abandoning the training, fell to Avīci hell. Though once esteemed, his envy led to ruin. The wise should associate with those whose path leads to the end of suffering.

conceit.title: Addhā sutta - The Three Times
conceit.description: The Buddha speaks on how beings cling to what can be expressed—concepts and designations, including the three times of past, future, and present. Not fully understanding these, they fall under the yoke of death. But one who sees beyond conceptual fabrications touches liberation and does not resort to mental proliferation.

conceit.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
conceit.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

conceit.title: Bāla vagga - Chapter 5 - Immature
conceit.description: DhammaPada verses 60-75 describe the traits and consequences for an immature person. They suffer from delusion, cling to false views of self and possessions, perform harmful actions, seek status without wisdom, and long for recognition. In contrast, the wise avoid their company and pursue seclusion and true understanding of the Dhamma.

conceit.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
conceit.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

conceit.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
conceit.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

conceit.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
conceit.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

conceit.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
conceit.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

conceit.title: Paṭhamaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (First)
conceit.description: The Buddha describes the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance that are present in living beings.

conceit.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
conceit.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

craving.title: Dutiyasatta sutta - Clinging (Second)
craving.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on harm that comes from sensual desire.

craving.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
craving.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

craving.title: Gantha sutta - Knots
craving.description: The four knots of 1) craving, 2) ill will, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to the idea that 'This is the truth' are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these knots.

craving.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
craving.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

craving.title: Gaṅgā sutta - Ganges
craving.description: The Buddha explains to a brahmin that the cycle of existence is without a discoverable beginning, and that it is not easy to calculate the number of aeons that have passed by and gone.

craving.title: Cūḷadukkhakkhandha sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
craving.description: A lay disciple asks the Buddha why greed, aversion, and illusion still occupy and remain in his mind. The Buddha explains the importance of cultivating discernment of the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures along with cultivating the joy and happiness apart from sensual pleasures. He then recounts a conversation with the Nigaṇṭhas on this topic.

craving.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
craving.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

craving.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
craving.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

craving.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
craving.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

craving.title: Duccarita sutta - Misconduct
craving.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of misconduct - by body, speech and mind.

craving.title: Nadīsota sutta - River Current
craving.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a person carried downstream by a lovely and alluring river current to illustrate the painful results of craving and indulgence in the internal sense bases.

craving.title: Taṇhuppāda sutta - Uprisings of Craving
craving.description: The Buddha describes the four uprisings of craving that can arise for a bhikkhu.

craving.title: Taṇhā vagga - Chapter 24 - Craving
craving.description: Dhammapada verses 334–359 depict craving as a binding force, likening it to a creeping vine, a trapped hare, and a spider’s web. The wise cut these bonds, free from passion, aversion, illusion, and longing, crossing beyond birth and aging. The highest gift is the Dhamma, surpassing all wealth and pleasures, and the destruction of craving is the greatest victory. Offerings to those free from defilements bear the greatest fruit.

craving.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
craving.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

craving.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
craving.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

craving.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
craving.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

cruelty.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

discontentment.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
discontentment.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

discontentment.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
discontentment.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

discontentment.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
discontentment.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

displeasure.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
displeasure.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

displeasure.title: Anaṅgaṇa sutta - Blemish Free

disturbed.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
disturbed.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

disturbed.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
disturbed.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

doubt.title: Orambhāgiya sutta - Lower Fetters
doubt.description: The five lower fetters - 1) personality view, 2) doubt, 3) attachment to rites and rituals, 4) sensual desire, and 5) ill will - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five lower fetters.

doubt.title: Nīvaraṇa sutta - Hindrances

The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

doubt.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies

doubt.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

drowsiness.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. drowsiness.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

dullness.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
dullness.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

dullness.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
dullness.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

faithlessness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
faithlessness.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

fearful.title: Kumāraka sutta - Boys
fearful.description: If suffering is displeasing to you, do not commit evil deeds, whether openly or in secret.

fearful.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
fearful.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

fearful.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
fearful.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

fearful.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
fearful.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

fearful.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
fearful.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. Through metaphors of a broken gong, a well-trained horse, and skilled artisans, the verses emphasize that true purification comes not from external austerities but from inner restraint, mindfulness, and ethical conduct. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

fearful.title: Paṭhama dāna sutta - Giving (First)
fearful.description: The Buddha explains eight kinds of giving, including giving out of fear, giving to maintain a good reputation, and giving to purify the mind.

feuding.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
feuding.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

feuding.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
feuding.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

greed.title: Verambha sutta - Turbulent
greed.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of turbulent winds high in the sky.

greed.title: Siṅgāla sutta - Jackal
greed.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of an old jackal with mange.

greed.title: Kumma sutta - The Turtle
greed.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a turtle struck by a harpoon to illustrate how attachments to acquisitions, respect, and popularity can lead to misfortune and hinder spiritual progress.

greed.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
greed.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

greed.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
greed.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions.
