greed.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
greed.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

greed.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
greed.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

harmful.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
harmful.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

harmful.title: Sanidāna sutta - From A Cause
harmful.description: The Buddha explains how thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming arise from a cause and how to abandon them.

harmful.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
harmful.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

harmful.title: Devadatta sutta - Devadatta
harmful.description: The Buddha explains how Devadatta, overcome by evil desires, bad friendship, and abandoning the training, fell to Avīci hell. Though once esteemed, his envy led to ruin. The wise should associate with those whose path leads to the end of suffering.

harmful.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding
harmful.description: The three unwholesome thoughts are blinding, produce lack of clarity, cause ignorance, obstruct wisdom, and are troublesome and not conducive to Nibbāna. The three wholesome thoughts give sight, produce clarity and create insight, grow wisdom, and are trouble-free and conducive to Nibbāna.

harmful.title: Sukhapatthanā sutta - Aspiring for Happiness
harmful.description: The Buddha teaches that a wise person aspiring for the three kinds of happiness - of 1) praise, 2) wealth, and 3) good rebirth - should safeguard their virtue.

harmful.title: Putta sutta - Child
harmful.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

harmful.title: Duccarita sutta - Misconduct
harmful.description: The Buddha describes the three kinds of misconduct - by body, speech and mind.

harmful.title: Cara sutta - Walking
harmful.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

harmful.title: Bāla vagga - Chapter 5 - Immature
harmful.description: DhammaPada verses 60-75 describe the traits and consequences for an immature person. They suffer from delusion, cling to false views of self and possessions, perform harmful actions, seek status without wisdom, and long for recognition. In contrast, the wise avoid their company and pursue seclusion and true understanding of the Dhamma.

harmful.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
harmful.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

harmful.title: Niraya vagga - Chapter 22 - Hell
harmful.description: Dhammapada verses 306–319 warn of the suffering that follows false speech, misconduct, and wrong view. The verses highlight the danger of negligence, hypocrisy, and slack effort in spiritual practice. Those who cultivate right view, ethical conduct, and firm effort attain a good destination, while those who embrace wrong views and harmful actions fall into misery.

harmful.title: Daṇḍa vagga - Chapter 10 - Punishment
harmful.description: Dhammapada verses 129-145 explore the themes of non-violence, the consequences of harmful actions, and the importance of self-discipline. The inevitability of death and the suffering caused by harming others are highlighted alongside the rewards of peace and wisdom for those who cultivate virtuous behavior.

harmful.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
harmful.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

harmful.title: Cara sutta - Walking
harmful.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

harmful.title: Devadūta sutta - Divine Messengers
harmful.description: The Buddha describes the three divine messengers that appear among human beings and what happens to those who do not heed their message.

harmful.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
harmful.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

harmful.title: Adanta vagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
harmful.description: Short teachings contrasting the untamed and the tamed mind.

harmful.title: Akammaniya vagga - The Chapter On The Ineffective
harmful.description: The Buddha contrasts the undeveloped and developed mind.

having many desires.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
having many desires.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

having many desires.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
having many desires.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

having many desires.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
having many desires.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

having many desires.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
having many desires.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

having many desires.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
having many desires.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

hypocrisy.title: Uposatha sutta - Uposatha
hypocrisy.description: The Buddha sits silently among the Saṅgha of bhikkhus on an Uposatha night when the assembly wasn't pure. Afterwards, the Buddha explains the eight wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Dhamma and Vinaya, likening them to similarly wonderful qualities of the great ocean.

hypocrisy.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
hypocrisy.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

hypocrisy.title: Kuha sutta - Deceitful
hypocrisy.description: The Buddha describes the qualities of true disciples, and those who do not grow in the Dhamma.

hypocrisy.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
hypocrisy.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

hypocrisy.title: Andha sutta - Blind
hypocrisy.description: The Buddha describes three types of people - the blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

ignorance.title: Ajitamāṇavapucchā - Ajita’s Questions
ignorance.description: Ajita asks the Buddha a series of questions about the nature of the world, the currents of defilements, how to overcome name and form and the conduct of those who have comprehended the Dhamma.

ignorance.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
ignorance.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

ignorance.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
ignorance.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

ignorance.title: Avijjāpahāna sutta - Abandoning Ignorance
ignorance.description: The Buddha teaches on how to know and see the impermanence of the six sense bases and the process leading up to the arising of feeling and perception for the abandoning of ignorance and the arising of wisdom.

ignorance.title: Pariñña sutta - Full Understanding
ignorance.description: The Buddha teaches the things to be fully understood and what full understanding is.

ignorance.title: Gaṅgā sutta - Ganges
ignorance.description: The Buddha explains to a brahmin that the cycle of existence is without a discoverable beginning, and that it is not easy to calculate the number of aeons that have passed by and gone.

ignorance.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
ignorance.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

ignorance.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
ignorance.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

ignorance.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
ignorance.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

ignorance.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
ignorance.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

ignorance.title: Dutiya rāga sutta - Passion (Second)
ignorance.description: Whoever has let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is called one who has crossed beyond the ocean—with its waves, currents, whirlpools, lurking with fierce animals and monsters.

ignorance.title: Paṭhama rāga sutta - Passion (First)
ignorance.description: Whoever has not let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is said to be bound by Māra, ensnared by Māra's trap, at the mercy of the Evil One, and subject to his will.

ignorance.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
ignorance.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

ignorance.title: Jarā vagga - Chapter 11 - Old Age
ignorance.description: Dhammapada verses 146–156 explore impermanence, the nature of the body, and the inevitability of aging and death. Through metaphors of a world ablaze, a decaying body, the house-builder and a city of bones, they point to life's transience and the futility of clinging to sensual pleasures. The verses highlight the cultivation of wisdom, detachment, and the pursuit of an unconditioned state beyond constructs, contrasting fleeting youth and inevitable old age with the timeless teachings that lead to liberation.

ignorance.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
ignorance.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

ignorance.title: Paṭhamaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (First)
ignorance.description: The Buddha describes the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance that are present in living beings.

ignorance.title: Kāyagatāsati vagga - The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body
ignorance.description: Short teachings on the benefits of cultivating mindfulness of the body.

ignorance.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
ignorance.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

illusion.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
illusion.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

illusion.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
illusion.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

illusion.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
illusion.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

illusion.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
illusion.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

illusion.title: Cūḷadukkhakkhandha sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
illusion.description: A lay disciple asks the Buddha why greed, aversion, and illusion still occupy and remain in his mind. The Buddha explains the importance of cultivating discernment of the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures along with cultivating the joy and happiness apart from sensual pleasures. He then recounts a conversation with the Nigaṇṭhas on this topic.

illusion.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
illusion.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

illusion.title: Antarāmala sutta - Internal Impurity
illusion.description: Greed, aversion, and illusion are internal impurities that act as one's internal enemies. Though they obscure clarity and injure one from within, most people fail to recognize their true nature.

immaturity.title: Uposatha sutta - Uposatha
immaturity.description: The Buddha sits silently among the Saṅgha of bhikkhus on an Uposatha night when the assembly wasn't pure. Afterwards, the Buddha explains the eight wonderful and marvelous qualities of the Dhamma and Vinaya, likening them to similarly wonderful qualities of the great ocean.

immaturity.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
immaturity.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

immaturity.title: Sukhapatthanā sutta - Aspiring for Happiness
immaturity.description: The Buddha teaches that a wise person aspiring for the three kinds of happiness - of 1) praise, 2) wealth, and 3) good rebirth - should safeguard their virtue.

immaturity.title: Paññāparihīna sutta - Lacking in Wisdom
immaturity.description: The Buddha describes the sentient beings who lack in wisdom as truly deprived, dwelling in suffering, annoyance, hardship, and distress.

Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

immaturity.title: Nāga vagga - Chapter 23 - The Elephant
immaturity.description: Dhammapada verses 320–333 highlight self-discipline, wisdom, and perseverance through the imagery of elephants. They highlight inner mastery over strength, the value of solitude over company of immature persons, and the importance of taming one’s mind. Honoring parents, cultivating virtue, and letting go of suffering lead to true ease.

immaturity.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
immaturity.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

immaturity.title: Atta vagga - Chapter 12 - Self
immaturity.description: Dhammapada verses 157-166 emphasize self-discipline, personal responsibility, and inner mastery. A wise person must first establish themselves properly before guiding others, as self-mastery is difficult but essential. Purity and impurity are personal matters, and one should prioritize their own spiritual welfare over external concerns, for no one can purify another.

immaturity.title: Pāpa vagga - Chapter 9 - Harm
immaturity.description: Dhammapada verses 116-128 share the importance of hastening to do good, restraining the mind from harm, the consequences of harm and good, the accumulation of evil and good, the importance of avoiding harmful actions, the consequences of harming a blameless person, the results of evil and good, and the inevitability of death.

impatience.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

impatience.title: Akkhama sutta - Unable to Endure
impatience.description: Using the example of a king’s elephant on the battlefield, the Buddha presents two contrasting scenarios - In one case, a person, overwhelmed by enticing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches is unable to collect and settle the mind; in the other, a person patiently endures without becoming infatuated with external objects, and is able to compose and stabilize the mind amidst sensory contact.

irritability.title: Kamboja sutta - Kamboja
irritability.description: The Buddha describes the cause and condition for why a woman neither sits in public assemblies, nor pursues occupations, nor journeys to Kamboja.

jealousy.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

jealousy.title: Kamboja sutta - Kamboja
jealousy.description: The Buddha describes the cause and condition for why a woman neither sits in public assemblies, nor pursues occupations, nor journeys to Kamboja.

laziness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
laziness.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

laziness.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
laziness.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

laziness.title: Dhātusosaṁsandana sutta - The Coming Together of Elements
laziness.description: Beings come together and associate with other beings according to their disposition. Therefore, one should avoid associating with those that are lazy and keep company with the wise.

laziness.title: Cara sutta - Walking
laziness.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

laziness.title: Magga vagga - Chapter 20 - The Path
laziness.description: Dhammapada verses 273–289 emphasize the eightfold path as the foremost way to liberation, seeing the impermanent, unsatisfactory, and not-self nature of all things. Further, the verses mention the relation of meditation and wisdom, They mention restraint, how wisdom through meditation, on cutting off the forest as well as the undergrowth, and making swift effort to purify by the way of practice leading to Nibbāna.

laziness.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
laziness.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

laziness.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
laziness.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

laziness.title: Anuruddhamahāvitakka sutta - Anuruddha and Thoughts of a Great Person
laziness.description: Venerable Anuruddha reflects on seven qualities conducive for practicing the Dhamma, but his thoughts are incomplete until the Buddha appears to add an eighth.

laziness.title: Cara sutta - Walking
laziness.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

laziness.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
laziness.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

laziness.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
laziness.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

laziness.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
laziness.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

laziness.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
laziness.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

mental proliferation.title: Papañcakhaya sutta - Wearing Away of Mental Proliferation
mental proliferation.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance after reflecting on his own giving up of the proliferation of conceptual perceptions.

mental proliferation.title: Addhā sutta - The Three Times
mental proliferation.description: The Buddha speaks on how beings cling to what can be expressed—concepts and designations, including the three times of past, future, and present. Not fully understanding these, they fall under the yoke of death. But one who sees beyond conceptual fabrications touches liberation and does not resort to mental proliferation.

mental proliferation.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain

mental proliferation.title: Anutappiya sutta - Regret
mental proliferation.description: One who delights in personal existence dies with regret and their passing away is not fortunate. One who delights in Nibbāna and gives up personal existence dies without regret and their passing away is fortunate.

mental proliferation.title: Bhaddaka sutta - Auspicious
mental proliferation.description: One who delights in personal existence does not have an auspicious death. One who delights in Nibbāna and gives up personal existence has an auspicious death.

moral recklessness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement

moral recklessness.title: Āpāyika sutta - Destined for Suffering
moral recklessness.description: The Buddha describes the two behaviors that lead to suffering and rebirth in hell if not abandoned.

muddle-minded.title: Sadhāyamāna sutta - Mocking
muddle-minded.description: The Blessed One sees a group of young brāhmaṇas passing by, appearing to be mocking.

muddle-minded.title: Uddhata sutta - Restless
muddle-minded.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance about the qualities of a person who falls under the sway of Māra and of one who overcomes all bad destinations.

muddle-minded.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
muddle-minded.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

muddle-minded.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
muddle-minded.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

muddle-minded.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
muddle-minded.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

negligence.title: Uṭṭhāna sutta - Rise Up
negligence.description: Verses urging one to rise from negligence, train steadfastly for the state of peace, and not waste the fleeting opportunity of the present moment. The teaching emphasizes the urgency of effort with the imagery of the afflicted pierced by a dart and the King of Death misleading one who remains negligent.

negligence.title: Vīṇopama sutta - Simile of the Lute
negligence.description: The Buddha explains how to rein in the mind when desire, passion, aversion, illusion, or repulsion arises in regard to the six sense bases using the simile of a watchman and an ox and the simile of a lute.

negligence.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
negligence.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

negligence.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
negligence.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

negligence.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
negligence.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

negligence.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
negligence.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

negligence.title: Putta sutta - Child
negligence.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

negligence.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
negligence.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

negligence.title: Niraya vagga - Chapter 22 - Hell
negligence.description: Dhammapada verses 306–319 warn of the suffering that follows false speech, misconduct, and wrong view. The verses highlight the danger of negligence, hypocrisy, and slack effort in spiritual practice. Those who cultivate right view, ethical conduct, and firm effort attain a good destination, while those who embrace wrong views and harmful actions fall into misery.

negligence.title: Pakiṇṇaka vagga - Chapter 21 - Assorted
negligence.description: Dhammapada verses 290–305 share on the renunciation of lesser happiness for greater joy, mindfulness of the body, and applying effort to overcome defilements. Further, the verses highlight the harm of neglecting what should be done, consequence of imposing suffering on another, while praising recollection of the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha as well as the qualities of mindfulness, non-violence, and cultivation. The verses conclude with the benefits of solitude and the wilderness for those who are energetic and self-restrained.

negligence.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
negligence.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

negligence.title: Appamādavagga - Chapter 2 - Diligence
negligence.description: DhammaPada verses 21-32 share the distinct path and outcomes of diligence and negligence. On seeing this clearly, the wise guard diligence like the most important wealth. One devoted to diligence burns away all fetters, is incapable of decline, and is near to Nibbāna.

negligence.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
negligence.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

negligence.title: Devadūta sutta - Divine Messengers
negligence.description: The Buddha describes the three divine messengers that appear among human beings and what happens to those who do not heed their message.

negligence.title: Dutiya pamādādi vagga - Second Chapter Starting With Negligence
negligence.description: The Buddha lists the mental qualities that form the internal factors leading to harm or benefit, the qualities that lead to the decline or continuity of the true Dhamma, and the actions that lead to the harm of many people.

negligence.title: Pamādādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning With Negligence
negligence.description: The Buddha explains the consequences of negligence and diligence, laziness and arousing of energy, having many desires and having few wishes, discontentment and contentment, unwise and wise attention, full awareness and lack of it, bad and good friendships, and good and bad habits.

negligence.title: Amata vagga - The Chapter On The Deathless
negligence.description: The Buddha explains the importance of mindfulness of the body in partaking in the deathless.

negligence.title: Vīriyārambhādi vagga - The Chapter Beginning with the Rousing of Energy
negligence.description: The Buddha explains the importance of rousing of energy and the consequences of having many desires, few desires, dissatisfaction, contentment, (careless) attention, wise attention, clear comprehension and lack of it, and bad friendship.

negligence.title: Accharāsaṅghāta vagga - The Chapter On A Finger Snap
negligence.description: The Buddha explains the importance of developing a radiant mind, a mind of loving-kindness and the consequences of negligence, diligence, and laziness.

non-restraint.title: Uddhata sutta - Restless
non-restraint.description: The Buddha expresses an inspired utterance about the qualities of a person who falls under the sway of Māra and of one who overcomes all bad destinations.

non-restraint.title: Chappāṇakopama sutta - The Simile of the Six Animals
non-restraint.description: The Buddha explains how there is non-restraint and restraint with a simile of six animals with different domains and feeding grounds. He uses strong post or pillar as a designation for mindfulness directed to the body.

non-restraint.title: Paṭhama parihāni sutta - Decline (First)
non-restraint.description: The Buddha explains seven things that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and seven things that do not.

non-restraint.title: Adanta vagga - The Chapter on the Untamed
non-restraint.description: Short teachings contrasting the untamed and the tamed mind.

passion.title: Dutiyasatta sutta - Clinging (Second)
passion.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on harm that comes from sensual desire.

passion.title: Uddhambhāgiya sutta - Higher Fetters
passion.description: The five higher fetters - 1) Passion for worldly existence, 2) passion for formless existence, 3) conceit, 4) restlessness, and 5) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five higher fetters.

passion.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
passion.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

passion.title: Caṇḍa sutta - Aggressive
passion.description: The Buddha explains the cause and condition by which a person comes to be recognized as aggressive or gentle. He illuminates how the presence or absence of passion, aversion, and illusion determines whether one is susceptible to provocation and reacts with anger, or remains unshaken.

passion.title: Upavāṇasandiṭṭhika sutta - Directly Visible with Upavāṇa
passion.description: The Buddha explains how the Dhamma is directly visible, immediate, inviting one to come and see, applicable, and to be personally experienced by the wise through the six sense bases.

passion.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
passion.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

passion.title: Ayyikā sutta - Grandmother
passion.description: King Pasenadi expresses deep sorrow over his grandmother's death. The Buddha teaches him that all beings, without exception, are subject to death and cannot escape it, likening it to a potter's pots that are all bound to break.

passion.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
passion.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

passion.title: Verambha sutta - Turbulent
passion.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of turbulent winds high in the sky.

passion.title: Siṅgāla sutta - Jackal
passion.description: The Buddha explains how acquisitions, respect, and popularity are harsh, bitter, and severe, obstructing the attainment of the unsurpassed safety from bondage, using a simile of an old jackal with mange.

passion.title: Kumma sutta - The Turtle
passion.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a turtle struck by a harpoon to illustrate how attachments to acquisitions, respect, and popularity can lead to misfortune and hinder spiritual progress.

passion.title: Māgaṇḍiya sutta - To Māgaṇḍiya
passion.description: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya holds the view that sensual indulgence is spiritual growth and harshly criticizes the Buddha for teaching sense restraint, calling him a destroyer of spiritual growth. The Buddha skilfully reveals the true nature of sensual pleasures through vivid similes such as a leper finding relief by scorching himself over burning coals and a blind man mistaking a filthy rag for a spotless white cloth.

passion.title: Mahārāhulovāda sutta - The Greater Discourse on Advice to Rāhula
passion.description: The Buddha instructs Rāhula on how to regard the five aggregates as not-self which he immediately applies to practice. The Buddha then teaches Rāhula on how to meditate on the elements, the divine abodes, unattractiveness, impermanence, and mindfulness of breathing to abandon unwholesome mental qualities and cultivate wholesome mental qualities.

passion.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
passion.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

passion.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
passion.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

passion.title: Bhayabherava sutta - Fright and Dread
passion.description: The Buddha explains to the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi how he overcame fright and dread while practicing seclusion in remote lodgings in the forests and woodlands, leading to the three true knowledges and full awakening.

passion.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
passion.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

passion.title: Aggi sutta - Fires
passion.description: The Buddha describes the fires of passion, hatred, and illusion which consume beings who cling to a self. The wise cool these flames with wisdom, loving-kindness, and perceiving unattractiveness.

passion.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
passion.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

passion.title: Asubhānupassī sutta - Contemplating Unattractiveness
passion.description: The Buddha advises to 1) dwell contemplating the unattractive nature of the body, 2) establish mindfulness as the first priority while breathing in and out, and 3) observe impermanence in all conditioned phenomena.

passion.title: Dutiya rāga sutta - Passion (Second)
passion.description: Whoever has let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is called one who has crossed beyond the ocean—with its waves, currents, whirlpools, lurking with fierce animals and monsters.

passion.title: Paṭhama rāga sutta - Passion (First)
passion.description: Whoever has not let go of passion, aversion, and illusion is said to be bound by Māra, ensnared by Māra's trap, at the mercy of the Evil One, and subject to his will.

passion.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
passion.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

passion.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
passion.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

passion.title: Paṭhamaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (First)
passion.description: The Buddha describes the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance that are present in living beings.

passion.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
passion.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

passion.title: Cittapariyādāna vagga - The Chapter on the Obsession of the Mind
passion.description: The Buddha explains how the mind can be obsessed by the senses.

personal existence.title: Mogharājamāṇavapucchā - Mogharāja’s Question
personal existence.description: The venerable Mogharāja asks the Buddha how to look upon the world so that the King of Death does not see one. The Buddha advises to look upon the world as empty, being ever mindful, and to uproot the sense of self.

personal existence.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
personal existence.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

personal existence.title: Salla sutta - Arrow
personal existence.description: The Buddha explains the difference between an uninstructed ordinary person and a learned noble disciple in how they experience pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings.

personal existence.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
personal existence.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

personal existence.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
personal existence.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

personal existence.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
personal existence.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

personal existence.title: Aggi sutta - Fires

personal existence.title: Parihāna sutta - Decline
personal existence.description: The Buddha describes three qualities that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and three qualities that lead to non-decline.

perturbation.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
perturbation.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

perturbation.title: Citta vagga - Chapter 3 - Mind
perturbation.description: DhammaPada verses 33-43 share about the nature of the mind, the drawbacks of an untamed mind, and the benefits of protecting and restraining the mind. Those who restrain the mind will be freed from the shackles of death. Not even one's own mother, father, or any other relatives can do as much good as a rightly oriented mind can.

regret.title: Bāla vagga - Chapter 5 - Immature
regret.description: DhammaPada verses 60-75 describe the traits and consequences for an immature person. They suffer from delusion, cling to false views of self and possessions, perform harmful actions, seek status without wisdom, and long for recognition. In contrast, the wise avoid their company and pursue seclusion and true understanding of the Dhamma.

resentment.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

resentment.title: Dhammadāyāda sutta - Heirs in the Dhamma
resentment.description: The Buddha illustrates that his true inheritance is the Dhamma, not material possessions. Venerable Sāriputta clarifies the practice of seclusion by listing numerous harmful qualities to abandon and the Middle Way that leads to abandoning of them, to clear vision, wisdom, tranquility, to full awakening.

resentment.title: Yamakavagga - Chapter 1 - Pairs
resentment.description: DhammaPada verses 1-20 share on the power of the mind in shaping one's experiences, the importance of letting go of resentment and hostility, the consequences of living without restraint and moderation, the distinction between essence and non-essence, the sorrow and joy tied to one's actions, the importance of acting according to the Dhamma, and who partakes in the true ascetic life.

resentment.title: Paṇihitaaccha vagga - The Chapter On Directing The Mind
resentment.description: The Buddha contrasts the misdirected and well-directed mind, and explains the importance of directing the mind.

sensual desire.title: Dutiyasatta sutta - Clinging (Second)
sensual desire.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on harm that comes from sensual desire.

sensual desire.title: Paṭhamasatta sutta - Clinging (First)
sensual desire.description: On seeing the people of Sāvatthi excessively clinging to sensual pleasures, the Buddha expresses an inspired utterance on the bondage that ensues from sensual desire.

sensual desire.title: Jatukaṇṇimāṇavapucchā - Jatukaṇṇi’s Questions
sensual desire.description: The venerable Jatukaṇṇi asks the Buddha on how to attain the state of peace and abandon birth and old age. The Buddha advises him to remove greed for sensual pleasures by seeing renunciation as safety, and to cease all grasping related to name and form in the past, future, as well as present.

sensual desire.title: Orambhāgiya sutta - Lower Fetters
sensual desire.description: The five lower fetters - 1) personality view, 2) doubt, 3) attachment to rites and rituals, 4) sensual desire, and 5) ill will - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five lower fetters.

sensual desire.title: Nīvaraṇa sutta - Hindrances
sensual desire.description: The five hindrances - 1) sensual desire, 2) ill will, 3) dullness and drowsiness, 4) restlessness and worry, and 5) doubt - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five hindrances.

sensual desire.title: Kāmaguṇa sutta - Cords of Sensual Pleasure
sensual desire.description: The five cords of sensual pleasure are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these five cords of sensual pleasure.

sensual desire.title: Anusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies
sensual desire.description: The seven underlying tendencies - 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) wrong view, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) attachment to existence, and 7) ignorance - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these tendencies.

sensual desire.title: Upādāna sutta - Clinging
sensual desire.description: The four kinds of clinging - 1) clinging to sensual pleasures, 2) clinging to views, 3) clinging to rules and observances, and 4) clinging to a doctrine of self - are described in brief. The Noble Eightfold Path is the way for direct knowledge, full understanding, complete exhaustion, and giving up of these four kinds of clinging.

sensual desire.title: Salla sutta - Arrow
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains the difference between an uninstructed ordinary person and a learned noble disciple in how they experience pleasant, painful, and neither-painful-nor-pleasant feelings.

sensual desire.title: Bāḷisikopama sutta - The Fisherman's Simile
sensual desire.description: The Buddha likens the six types of desirable sense objects to baited hooks, set in the world for the misfortune of beings—those who cling to them fall under Māra’s power.

sensual desire.title: Paṭhamarūpārāma sutta - Delight in Forms
sensual desire.description: The Buddha contrasts the suffering experienced by gods and humans, who delight in impermanent sense objects, with the contentment of the Tathāgata who understands their true nature, highlighting the differing views of happiness held by the world and the Noble Ones.

sensual desire.title: Sakkapañha sutta - Sakka's Question
sensual desire.description: The Buddha answers Sakka's question on the causes and supporting conditions whereby some beings do not attain Nibbāna in this very life and some beings do attain Nibbāna in this very life.

sensual desire.title: Bhāra sutta - Burden
sensual desire.description: What is the burden and who bears it, what is the taking up of the burden and the putting down of it.

sensual desire.title: Aniccasaññā sutta - Recognition Of Impermanence
sensual desire.description: The Buddha shares vivid similes to illustrate the benefits of developing the recognition of impermanence. This practice gradually exhausts all passion for sensual pleasure, materiality, becoming, ignorance, and uproots the conceit ‘I am.’

sensual desire.title: Sanidāna sutta - From A Cause
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains how thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming arise from a cause and how to abandon them.

sensual desire.title: Samiddhi sutta - With Samiddhi
sensual desire.description: A radiant deity tempts young Samiddhi to enjoy sensual pleasures. The Buddha later reveals that true liberation transcends identity and craving, and is only found by those who let go of even the need to describe themselves.

sensual desire.title: Māgaṇḍiya sutta - To Māgaṇḍiya
sensual desire.description: The wanderer Māgaṇḍiya holds the view that sensual indulgence is spiritual growth and harshly criticizes the Buddha for teaching sense restraint, calling him a destroyer of spiritual growth. The Buddha skilfully reveals the true nature of sensual pleasures through vivid similes such as a leper finding relief by scorching himself over burning coals and a blind man mistaking a filthy rag for a spotless white cloth.

sensual desire.title: Vattha sutta - The Simile of the Cloth
sensual desire.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a defiled cloth to explain how the mind can be similarly defiled by various impurities, and how it can be purified by abandoning them. And it is through this very practice that one arrives at unshakeable faith in the Buddha, the Dhamma, and the Saṅgha. The Buddha also addresses a brahmin in verses who believes in purification by bathing in river.

sensual desire.title: Laṭukikopama sutta - Simile of the Quail
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains how even small attachments can be strong fetters if not relinquished, using similes of a quail and an elephant, and contrasts between the poor and wealthy. He describes four types of practitioners based on their response to attachment and mindfulness. The discourse also presents gradual refinement of meditative attainments from the first jhāna to the cessation of perception and feeling.

sensual desire.title: Cūḷadhammasamādāna sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Cases of Taking up Practices
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains the four cases of taking up practices, based on whether they are pleasant or painful now and whether they ripen as suffering or a pleasant abiding in the future.

sensual desire.title: Cūḷadukkhakkhandha sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
sensual desire.description: A lay disciple asks the Buddha why greed, aversion, and illusion still occupy and remain in his mind. The Buddha explains the importance of cultivating discernment of the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures along with cultivating the joy and happiness apart from sensual pleasures. He then recounts a conversation with the Nigaṇṭhas on this topic.

sensual desire.title: Mahādukkhakkhandha sutta - The Greater Discourse on the Mass of Suffering
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains how to completely comprehend the gratification, drawback, and escape in the case of sensual pleasures, form, and felt experience.

sensual desire.title: Cūḷasīhanāda sutta - The Shorter Discourse on the Lion's Roar
sensual desire.description: The Buddha outlines an approach to cross-examine other sects and their doctrines, and how to distinguish between the true Dhamma and the false Dhamma through the comprehension of the four kinds of clinging.

sensual desire.title: Gopakamoggallāna sutta - With Gopaka Moggallāna
sensual desire.description: Shortly after the Buddha's final Nibbāna, Venerable Ānanda addresses the brahmins Gopaka Moggallāna and chief minister Vassakāra, clarifying that the Buddha appointed no successor, establishing the Dhamma itself as the refuge for the Saṅgha. He outlines ten qualities that make a bhikkhu worthy of veneration and distinguishes the meditations praised by the Buddha from those based on hindrances.

sensual desire.title: Kāmayoga sutta - Yoke of Sensual Pleasures
sensual desire.description: The Buddha classifies beings according to their attachment or detachment from sensual pleasures and conditioned existence. Those entangled in both are returners; those detached from sensual pleasures but still bound to existence are non-returners; and those freed from both are arahants who have ended the taints.

sensual desire.title: Kāmūpapatti sutta - Rebirths in the Sensual Realm
sensual desire.description: The Buddha describes three kinds of beings who partake in sensual pleasures - 1) those who enjoy what is presently available, 2) those who delight in their own creations, and 3) those who wield power over the creations of others.

sensual desire.title: Saṅghāṭikaṇṇa sutta - Corner of Robe
sensual desire.description: The Buddha teaches that one could be far from him despite being physically close, and one could be near to him despite being physically far. When one sees the Dhamma, one sees the Buddha.

sensual desire.title: Andhakaraṇa sutta - Blinding
sensual desire.description: The three unwholesome thoughts are blinding, produce lack of clarity, cause ignorance, obstruct wisdom, and are troublesome and not conducive to Nibbāna. The three wholesome thoughts give sight, produce clarity and create insight, grow wisdom, and are trouble-free and conducive to Nibbāna.

sensual desire.title: Cara sutta - Walking
sensual desire.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

sensual desire.title: Nadīsota sutta - River Current
sensual desire.description: The Buddha uses the simile of a person carried downstream by a lovely and alluring river current to illustrate the painful results of craving and indulgence in the internal sense bases.

sensual desire.title: Puppha vagga - Chapter 4 - Flowers
sensual desire.description: DhammaPada verses 44-59 share on the trainee, nature of the body, what happens to one who dwells with an attached mind, how a sage should wander in village, one who speaks on virtue and wisdom though various similes. The fragrance of virtue is compared to the fragrance of flowers, and the virtue of the noble person is said to spread in all directions.

sensual desire.title: Brāhmaṇa vagga - Chapter 26 - The Sage
sensual desire.description: Dhammapada verses 383–423 redefine 'Brāhmaṇa' (sage) by inner attainment, not birth or appearance. Through effort, a true sage cuts craving, understands reality, and realizes Nibbāna. Fearless, detached, pure, and restrained, they embody non-violence and patience. Free from defilements and attachments, having overcome suffering and rebirth, the sage achieves the ultimate goal, radiating wisdom and peace.

sensual desire.title: Bhikkhu vagga - Chapter 25 - Bhikkhu
sensual desire.description: Dhammapada verses 360–382 depict the ideal bhikkhu as one who restrains the senses, body, speech, and mind, leading to freedom from suffering. Emphasis is placed on mindfulness, inner joy, collectedness, and self-reliance. Through discipline and reflection, the bhikkhu advances towards the peace of Nibbāna, shining like the moon freed from clouds.

sensual desire.title: Piya vagga - Chapter 16 - Beloved
sensual desire.description: DhammaPada verses 209–220 explore the danger of attachment to what is pleasing, how sorrow and fear arise from the beloved, fondness, delight, sensual pleasures, and craving, who is dear to the people, who flows upstream, and on the importance of merit.

sensual desire.title: Paṭhama parihāni sutta - Decline (First)
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains seven things that lead to the decline of a trainee bhikkhu and seven things that do not.

sensual desire.title: Dutiyaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (Second)
sensual desire.description: The spiritual life is lived for the abandoning and complete uprooting of the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance.

sensual desire.title: Paṭhamaanusaya sutta - Underlying Tendencies (First)
sensual desire.description: The Buddha describes the seven underlying tendencies toward 1) sensual desire, 2) aversion, 3) views, 4) doubt, 5) conceit, 6) passion for existence, and 7) ignorance that are present in living beings.

sensual desire.title: Akkhama sutta - Unable to Endure
sensual desire.description: Using the example of a king’s elephant on the battlefield, the Buddha presents two contrasting scenarios - In one case, a person, overwhelmed by enticing sights, sounds, smells, tastes, and touches is unable to collect and settle the mind; in the other, a person patiently endures without becoming infatuated with external objects, and is able to compose and stabilize the mind amidst sensory contact.

sensual desire.title: Cara sutta - Walking
sensual desire.description: The Buddha describes two types of bhikkhus based on how they deal with thoughts of sensuality, ill will, and harming while walking, standing, sitting, and lying down, and which one is capable of reaching the highest awakening.

sensual desire.title: Andha sutta - Blind
sensual desire.description: The Buddha describes three types of people - the blind, the one-eyed, and the two-eyed.

sensual desire.title: Nīvaraṇappahāna vagga - The Chapter On The Abandoning Of The Hindrances
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains what causes the hindrances to arise and how to abandon them.

sensual desire.title: Cittapariyādāna vagga - The Chapter on the Obsession of the Mind
sensual desire.description: The Buddha explains how the mind can be obsessed by the senses.

sexual misconduct.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
sexual misconduct.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

sexual misconduct.title: Putta sutta - Child
sexual misconduct.description: Three kinds of children - 1) one who surpasses their parents, 2) one who follows in their footsteps, and 3) one who falls below them.

sexual misconduct.title: Niraya vagga - Chapter 22 - Hell
sexual misconduct.description: Dhammapada verses 306–319 warn of the suffering that follows false speech, misconduct, and wrong view. The verses highlight the danger of negligence, hypocrisy, and slack effort in spiritual practice. Those who cultivate right view, ethical conduct, and firm effort attain a good destination, while those who embrace wrong views and harmful actions fall into misery.

sexual misconduct.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
sexual misconduct.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

shamelessness.title: Hiri sutta - Conscience
shamelessness.description: Verses describing the characteristics of a false friend—one who disregards conscience and speaks without sincerity—contrasted with a true friend whose loyalty is unbreakable and whose actions reflect inner integrity. It further speaks to the joy and peace found in virtuous conduct, seclusion, and the realization of the Dhamma.

shamelessness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
shamelessness.description: The Buddha distinguishes peaceful abidings in the here and now from the way of effacement leading upwards to complete quenching. Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

shamelessness.title: Āpāyika sutta - Destined for Suffering
shamelessness.description: The Buddha describes the two behaviors that lead to suffering and rebirth in hell if not abandoned.

shamelessness.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
shamelessness.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

Effacement is shown as the gradual chipping away of defilements through restraint, cultivation of the noble eightfold path, and diligent training, culminating in the complete freedom of Nibbāna.

slaughtering.title: Jīvaka sutta - Discourse with Jīvaka
slaughtering.description: The Buddha explains to Jīvaka the circumstances in which meat may be consumed and the demerit of slaughtering living beings for the Tathāgata or his disciples.

slaughtering.title: Mahākammavibhaṅga sutta - Great Exposition on Action
slaughtering.description: Prompted by a misquotation of the Buddha regarding mental versus physical and verbal actions, the Buddha clarifies the nature of kamma and its results. He explains, through a framework of four paradoxical cases, how actions may lead to unexpected outcomes based on prior deeds or conditions at death.

slaughtering.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
slaughtering.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

sorrow.title: Salla sutta - The Dart
sorrow.description: Verses depicting the uncertain, brief, and suffering-laden nature of mortal life, emphasizing the inevitability of death for all beings, like ripe fruits fated to fall. The Buddha counsels against futile grief and lamentation over the departed, urging the wise to understand the world's relentless course of decay and death.

stinginess.title: Caṅkī sutta - With Caṅkī
stinginess.description: The Buddha answers the questions of the reputed brahmin Caṅkī's learned student, who asks the Buddha on how there is preservation of truth, awakening to the truth, final arrival at the truth, and what is most helpful for the final arrival at the truth.

stinginess.title: Avuṭṭhika sutta - Rainless
stinginess.description: Three kinds of persons are found in the world - 1) one like a rainless cloud, 2) one like a cloud that rains in a certain area, and 3) one like a cloud that rains everywhere.

stinginess.title: Dhammaṭṭha vagga - Chapter 19 - Firmly Established In The Dhamma
stinginess.description: Dhammapada verses 256-272 emphasize the qualities that define true wisdom, nobility, and spiritual attainment. These verses critique superficial markers such as age, outward appearance, or rituals. The chapter underscores the importance of avoiding harm, evaluating actions with discernment, and not resting content until there is the complete elimination of mental defilements.

stinginess.title: Mala vagga - Chapter 18 - Stain
stinginess.description: Dhammapada verses 235-255 emphasize on the urgency of striving swiftly, not being negligent, discerning gradually, stains of various qualities. A contrast is drawn on the lives of one who is shameless and one with a sense of right and wrong, on finding the faults of others and one's own, and on the path of the Tathāgatas.

stinginess.title: Kamboja sutta - Kamboja
stinginess.description: The Buddha describes the cause and condition for why a woman neither sits in public assemblies, nor pursues occupations, nor journeys to Kamboja.

stubbornness.title: Sallekha sutta - Effacement
